data.title: ICYMI from the Jersey City Times: Steve Fulop is the Wrong Choice for New Jersey
data.description:
“Our 49th mayor’s record has been one marked by corruption, maladministration, and gross indifference to the needs of his constituents.”

"The odor of corruption surrounding Fulop would persist throughout his three terms as mayor."

“Fulop deftly turned his mayoralty into an ATM for his campaign coffers and extracted sweetheart deals from those with business before the city”

“For voters who believe that Democrats should stand up for working people, Fulop has been a nightmare”


BLOOMFIELD — In case you missed it, Steven Fulop’s hometown paper issued a damning editorial outlining the many reasons why Fulop is the wrong choice for New Jersey — and they certainly brought the receipts. Chief among them: Fulop’s long history of corruption and pay-to-play politics that has sold Jersey City out to the highest bidder at the expense of working families. As the Jersey City Times pointedly said: “[T]he corruption, self-dealing, and maladministration that have characterized his tenure are disqualifying.” 

Read it for yourself here and below: 

Jersey City Times Editorial: Steve Fulop is the Wrong Choice for New Jersey

In two weeks, Democratic voters will choose their standard bearer for governor. There’s one candidate we can’t recommend: Steven M. Fulop. Our 49th mayor’s record has been one marked by corruption, maladministration, and gross indifference to the needs of his constituents.

As soon as Steve Fulop took office, it became clear that his claim to be a good-government reformer was at best, insincere. Jersey City began doling out contracts to campaign contributors, making a mockery of the “pay-to-play” ordinance that Fulop had championed as a councilman. 

Fulop quickly awarded a lucrative contract to a law firm that had illegally funneled money to his campaign through the use of “straw donors.” Two attorneys from the firm were indicted, but not before their firm had billed Jersey City three-quarters of a million dollars for their work.

The odor of corruption surrounding Fulop would persist throughout his three terms as mayor. With Fulop’s apparent approval, political operative and former Fulop campaign manager Tom Bertoli, set up shop at the Building Department, making key decisions and extracting payments for “expediting” building plans. Bertoli would ultimately be indicted and pled guilty for failing to report years of Jersey City-derived income.

In 2014, two of Fulop’s lieutenants were caught on tape trying to steer a city contract to a favored company, circumventing a public bidding process. Last year, Fulop’s once-close ally, Sudhan Thomas, was sentenced for embezzling money from the Jersey City Employment and Training Program. Thomas was also indicted for allegedly accepting cash in exchange for promising to hire a lawyer for the Board of Education on which he served as president.

Sadly, a whiff of corruption swirled around Fulop before he was elected mayor. For five months, his administration has stonewalled the production of documents related to an investigation into voter fraud in his 2005 campaign for City Council.

Fulop deftly turned his mayoralty into an ATM for his campaign coffers and extracted sweetheart deals from those with business before the city. Owners and investors in recently bankrupt CarePoint Health, which operates Christ Hospital, contributed close to $2 million to Fulop’s super PAC. Over $6 million in Fulop’s campaign coffers came directly the from real estate interests. 

After Fulop worked to lower the tax bill for the defunct Australia-based developer Dixon Advisory, Dixon renovated his home and built his beachfront house in Rhode Island. Dixon later gave Fulop an insider deal on a new trophy home complete with a rooftop swimming pool. 

Fulop’s record governing has been no better than his ethics. Under his watch, violent crime increased, despite his many claims to the contrary. Jersey City has become one of the most expensive and unaffordable cities in the country. A 2023 study found Jersey City to be the fifth dirtiest city in America. And poor planning and uncontrolled growth has brought traffic to a standstill on many of the city’s streets.

Fulop has been more than willing to use financial chicanery to avoid the political costs of fiscal honesty. In the view of experts, his administration cooked the city’s 2021 books to forestall an inevitable election year tax hike, a move lambasted by auditors. Rather than pay the bills his administration had incurred, he put $57 million on the city’s charge card, limiting a future mayor’s ability to borrow for legitimate purposes. The same year, he moved the cost of garbage collection off the city’s books to an autonomous agency, which promptly imposed an infamous “water tax” on residents.

For voters who believe that Democrats should stand up for working people, Fulop has been a nightmare. One of his first acts as mayor was to cancel a revaluation of Jersey City properties. The move, which was condemned by a state court judge, shifted $143 million in taxes from the wealthy Downtown to the city’s far less affluent neighborhoods. In his twelve years at the helm, Mayor Fulop couldn’t find the funds to build a single recreation center, in city that has none, for its youth. Meanwhile, he pushed through a $150 million tax abatement, and a commitment to spend millions more, to build a French art museum proposed by Charles Kushner but opposed by a broad coalition of local residents, including the arts community.

Despite his claims on the campaign trail, Fulop’s administration has been anything but transparent. Without explanation, he stopped publishing “CompStat” crime data in 2019, only to begin dribbling out data in the last year as he geared up his run for governor. He has been sued repeatedly for refusing to turn over information under New Jersey’s Open Public Records Act. In apparent retaliation for an article questioning his record on crime, Fulop blacklisted the Jersey City Times for close to two years. 

[...] 

These positives do not outweigh his far more numerous negatives. In our view, the corruption, self-dealing, and maladministration that have characterized his tenure are disqualifying. He should go nowhere near one of the most powerful governorships in the country with responsibility for a $58 billion budget.

Where does that leave Democratic voters? It’s simple. There are five other candidates. Examine their records carefully. We are confident voters can find a better choice than our mayor.
 

###

data.title: Senate Majority Leader M. Teresa Ruiz Endorses Mikie Sherrill for Governor
data.description:
BLOOMFIELD — Senate Majority Leader M. Teresa Ruiz (LD-27) endorsed Mikie Sherrill for Governor of New Jersey today, citing Mikie’s dedication to New Jersey’s families and her lifelong commitment to defending our rights and freedoms. 

“I have worked side by side with Mikie for years, and at every turn, I have seen a fierce fighter for families and freedom. Mikie’s a working mother, and it’s why I believe she is a passionate advocate for making child care more affordable and ensuring every child in New Jersey, regardless of ZIP code, gets a great education. These issues are paramount to improving the quality of life for families today and tomorrow, and I know Mikie Sherrill will be a champion who is deeply committed to building opportunity for the next generation — and who won’t back down from tough challenges,” said Senate Majority Leader M. Teresa Ruiz. “As our rights and freedoms are under attack from Trump’s Washington, including reproductive rights, there will be no greater ally for our daughters and women in New Jersey than Mikie Sherrill. We need Mikie as governor, and together, we will chart a new path forward for our state.” 

“Teresa and I have talked many times about the importance of women’s leadership. Child care, education, and reproductive rights often get overlooked, but as mothers, we know they set the foundation for strong families and a strong economy. New Jersey cannot afford a Republican governor like Jack Ciattarelli, who will defund Planned Parenthood, underfund public education, and sit back as Donald Trump destroys our economy. Too many parents are struggling to get by right now, and I am going to be relentlessly focused on driving down everyday costs and building the brightest possible future for our children. Teresa is a champion in this space, I am ready to work with her to make that future a reality, and I am honored to have her endorsement,” said Mikie Sherrill. 

Senate Majority Leader Ruiz is the highest-ranking Latina legislator in State history. She previously served as chair of the Senate Education Committee, and held the positions of Assistant Majority Leader from 2010-2017 and Senate President Pro Tempore from 2018-2021. She and Mikie have worked together closely on expanding quality high-impact tutoring, child care, and reproductive rights. 
 

###

data.title: Billie Jean King Endorses Mikie Sherrill for Governor
data.description:
Billie Jean King Endorses Mikie Sherrill for Governor 
 

BLOOMFIELD — Today, Billie Jean King — a women’s sports legend and American icon — endorsed Mikie Sherrill for governor, citing her strong leadership for women and families. 

“Mikie Sherrill has delivered for her constituents in Congress and I know she will bring that same tenacity and fight for women and families as New Jersey’s next governor,” said Billie Jean King. “As a young woman in the Navy at a time when she was one of the few women pilots, Mikie was tested and learned how to lead. She has the backbone to defend our freedoms and our rights. With so much on the line, I hope you’ll get out to vote for Mikie early or on June 10.”

“When I think of leaders my daughters can look up to, Billie Jean King is at the top of the list. She paved the way for women athletes through a spectacular career on the court, but didn’t stop there. She has used her voice to fight for abortion rights and our LGBTQ community. Billie Jean is the definition of a trailblazer, and that’s why I’m so humbled to have her support in this campaign,” said Mikie Sherrill. 

Last year, Mikie co-led the legislative effort to award Billie Jean King the Congressional Gold Medal — making her the first individual female athlete to receive Congress’ highest honor. Mikie has long been a champion for Title IX in athletics and worked to address the dramatic inequities between men’s and women’s collegiate athletics. She also helped secure passage of the Equal Pay for Team USA Act, which now requires that athletes representing the U.S. in global amateur athletic competitions, no matter their gender, receive equal compensation and benefits in their sport. 

Mikie has also been endorsed by Maine Governor Janet Mills, U.S. Rep. Sarah McBride, EMILYs List, Latina Civic PAC, Elect Democratic Women, Chatham Moms for Change, Morris County Democratic Women’s Caucus, the Democratic Task Force of the Women’s Political Caucus of New Jersey, Vote Mama, National Women’s Political Caucus, and more. 

###

data.title: Sierra Club Endorses Mikie Sherrill for Governor
data.description:
Sierra Club Endorses Mikie Sherrill for Governor 

Second Endorsement by Major Environmental Group for Sherrill

MADISON — The New Jersey Chapter of the Sierra Club today announced its endorsement of Mikie Sherrill for Governor, citing her outstanding record on environmental issues in Congress and her bold vision to tackle these challenges as New Jersey’s next governor. The Sierra Club is the nation’s oldest and largest grassroots environmental organization, and invited all candidates to be considered for this endorsement.  

“Throughout her career, Mikie Sherrill has been a critical voice for protecting public health and lowering costs for her constituents. She has fought to preserve America’s public lands, address the root causes of the rise in extreme weather and flooding affecting states like New Jersey, and voted to make the largest ever investment in our environment—helping spark our nation’s manufacturing boom and make energy costs more affordable for families and small businesses. On behalf of the tens of thousands of Sierra Club members and supporters in New Jersey and millions more nationwide, we are proud to endorse Mikie Sherrill and we look forward to doing all we can to help elect her as Governor,” said Ben Jealous, Sierra Club Executive Director. 

“We are proud to officially announce our endorsement of Mikie Sherrill for New Jersey Governor as her campaign strongly aligns with Sierra Club’s vision for our affordable, 100% clean energy future. She is dedicated to protecting our right to breathe clean air and drink clean water, promoting public health and keeping communities safe, defending our public lands, and defending our state against attacks from the Trump Administration. Rep. Sherrill has an excellent track record that has proven her to be an environmental champion, including securing bipartisan funding for clean energy projects and flood protections, supporting the Great American Outdoors Act, the Gateway project, protecting people from toxic PFAS pollution, and more,” said Anjuli Ramos-Busot, Director of the NJ Sierra Club. “This year’s Gubernatorial primary is a critical race to decide the future of our state, and we need a strong leader who can stand up to a potential MAGA Republican to ensure New Jersey communities and our environment are protected. We are proud to endorse Congresswoman Sherrill because we know she will fight for New Jersey’s environment, public health, and economy.”

“The New Jersey Sierra Club is a people power house that is ready and fired up to knock doors, speak out, and elect Mikie Sherrill for the next Governor of New Jersey. The Chapter has historically supported Sherrill’s campaign going back to 2018, when she flipped her Republican district,” said Rich Isaac, NJ Sierra Club Chapter Chair. “Congresswoman Sherrill is such a versatile candidate who has truly shown herself to be a champion for the environment. We are confident that she will protect our state from harmful rollbacks from the Trump Administration at the Federal level to ensure that New Jerseyans are able to access the outdoors, breathe clean air, drink clean water, and continue towards a clean energy future.”

“There’s nothing more important than delivering a better future for our kids. I’m raising four and we have a responsibility to their generation and those that follow to protect our environment and solve the energy crisis facing our state and country,” said Mikie Sherrill. “The Sierra Club was with me back in the early days of 2018 when we flipped a district and I couldn’t be prouder to have them on the team in this race for governor. Together, we’re going to protect our communities from flooding and climate change, lower utility costs with clean, cheap power like solar, and stand up to Trump’s attacks on our planet, our state, and our future.” 

Mikie is the candidate for environmental voters — she has also been endorsed by the League of Conservation Voters. Her Affordability Agenda includes bold proposals to invest in clean, cheap power like solar to protect our environment and lower utility costs in New Jersey. She has committed to streamlining approvals to bring clean energy online, and holding PJM, our regional grid operator, accountable for connecting the backlog of clean, cheap power to the grid. Mikie has also proposed more investments in community solar, hosting more clean energy on state properties, and collaborating with neighboring states to improve energy infrastructure and battery storage, which will all lower costs for New Jerseyans. 

Rep. Sherrill has been an environmental champion in Congress and knows how to deliver on New Jersey’s priorities. She collaborated with municipalities to deliver federal funding for flood mitigation along the Whippany River and, after decades of delays, advanced flood mitigation projects with the Army Corps of Engineers. Mikie has also helped communities in NJ-11 advance lead service line replacement and combat PFAS (forever chemicals). And she has championed efforts to increase the use of native plants at federal facilities in New Jersey and across the country. She will bring that same tenacity and resolve to the governor’s office. 

About the New Jersey Sierra Club:

The Sierra Club is America’s largest and most influential grassroots environmental organization, with millions of members and supporters. In addition to protecting every person's right to get outdoors and access the healing power of nature, the Sierra Club works to promote clean energy, safeguard the health of our communities, protect wildlife, and preserve our remaining wild places through grassroots activism, public education, lobbying, and legal action. For more information, visit www.sierraclub.org.
 

###

data.title: Mikie Sherrill Stands with State Legislators, Providers in Defense of Abortion Rights
data.description:
MONTCLAIR — Today, Mikie Sherrill stood with providers and seven of New Jersey’s state legislators to outline the stakes of abortion rights in New Jersey. As Trump abandons protections for emergency abortion care, and as Jack Ciattarelli runs on a promise to defund Planned Parenthood and support an abortion ban, it’s critical that New Jersey elects a governor with the track record to beat him and protect abortion rights in the Garden State. That’s Mikie Sherrill.

“We all thought our rights were safe before Roe fell. And then when that decision came down, we were all shocked and horrified. We cannot be caught flat-footed again. And when I’m governor, we won’t. We know what we are up against: Jack Ciattarelli has already vowed to ban abortion and defund Planned Parenthood. I’m running for governor because the stakes are so high, and I am the one who can beat him and protect our state. I am running to be a shield for the women of New Jersey and the next generation. At the age of 18, I signed up to put everything up to my life on the line for our freedom, and I’m sure as hell not stopping now,” said Mikie Sherrill.

Mikie was joined by Dr. Kristyn Brandi, Maxine Fine, Senate Majority Leader M. Teresa Ruiz, Senator Renee Burgess, Senator Linda Greenstein, Assemblywoman Rosy Bagolie, Assemblywoman Alixon Collazos-Gill, Assemblywoman Tennille McCoy, and Assemblywoman Carmen Morales.

“I know that there are so many reasons why our governor’s race is critical this year, but of course, I am concerned about how the next governor is going to set the stage for how people in New Jersey will be able to access abortion care. I can’t imagine a worse thing for our state in this moment than a Republican like Jack Ciattarelli bringing the Trump agenda to our front door. Mikie will protect abortion rights and providers like me so I can take care of whoever walks in my door, and give me the tools like mifepristone so I can use the best evidence to care for people in NJ and beyond,” said Dr. Kristyn Brandi. 

“I was a nursing student when a young woman came into our emergency room bleeding to death because she had gone for a back-alley abortion, and she died before she could be operated on. I never thought that near the end of my career we would be in the same place we were when I started my career nearly 40 years ago. Women should have a choice whether to have a baby or not. What people need to understand is that cutbacks to Planned Parenthood aren’t all about abortion. It’s about education and teaching people about the options they have. We need to have the freedom to support ourselves, our families, and our communities. I am here because Mikie Sherrill will protect and advance those rights,” said Maxine Fine.

“I was in the legislature when budgets for reproductive health were struck, when the entire Planned Parenthood line was erased. We can’t go back to those times. It’s egregious that I have an eight-year-old daughter at home who has less bodily autonomy than her grandmother had. New Jersey has to stand up, and there is no better person than Mikie Sherrill to lead the charge. She’s already fought the good fight down in the federal government, and she is ready to take the reins in the Garden State to protect my daughter, my daughter’s daughter, and women across our state,” said Senate Majority Leader M. Teresa Ruiz. 

“Mikie is a wife, mom, and has fought for our country, so she knows what it is to fight for reproductive freedom. We already know what we have, and we refuse to go backward. Let’s put up the fight — get your friends out to knock on doors and make phone calls from now until June 10 — to make sure that Mikie Sherrill becomes our next governor,” said Senator Renee Burgess.

“Over 25 years in the legislature, I have faced so many challenges, particularly when Governor Christie defunded Planned Parenthood — which Jack Ciattarelli was all too happy to vote for. Jack wants to bring Trump’s agenda to New Jersey, and the only way to fight that is to elect Mikie Sherrill as governor. On reproductive rights in particular, Mikie has been a leader. She is the best candidate to not only stand up to attacks on reproductive rights, but to champion our freedoms. We are going forward with Mikie, not backward with Jack,” said Senator Linda Greenstein.

“As an educator and now legislator, I've seen firsthand what happens when you strip people of their dignity and their rights, especially over the right to control their own bodies. If Jack Ciattarelli becomes governor, reproductive rights in New Jersey will be under direct threat. We know that in the state of New Jersey, the only person fighting to protect those rights today is Mikie Sherrill. That’s why I’m standing with Mikie — she’s not just talking, she’s leading. She is taking on the extremists implementing a national abortion ban, working to protect access to emergency abortion care, and she has been committed to locking these rights into our state constitution. We believe in Mikie to keep all women protected in the state of New Jersey,” said Assemblywoman Rosy Bagolie.

“The right to choose is not just a women’s issue — it’s a family issue, and it’s a community issue. When a woman can make decisions about her own body, healthcare, and future, her family, her future, and her community benefits. Here in New Jersey, we’ve been proud to lead. We’ve passed strong protections to save our access to abortion and reproductive health care. But we cannot take this progress for granted. We need to remain vigilant in defense of our reproductive freedoms, which is why I am standing with Mikie Sherrill to be the next Governor of New Jersey. She has not only spoken out about this issue, but she has acted on it. That’s the type of leadership we need in New Jersey,” said Assemblywoman Alixon Collazos-Gill.

“This is bigger than politics. As a state legislator, I’ve heard from young women, nurses, and doctors. We are under attack when it comes to reproductive rights, and it is heartbreaking as we see women turned away from hospitals, doctors being silenced, and families in crisis. The Republicans have already told us what they plan to do. Defund Planned Parenthood, restrict abortion rights, limit birth control. I didn’t take office to limit reproductive rights, because government shouldn’t be a sword; it should be a shield. That’s why I support Mikie Sherrill for governor. She will stand by each and every one of us and be our champion in Trenton,” said Assemblywoman Tennille McCoy. 

“As a legislator, as a mother, as a woman, I know how urgent and personal this issue is. We are facing a dangerous threat. Jack Ciattarelli has already shown us his values, he voted to uphold Christie’s budget cuts to Planned Parenthood. And now, he says he will bring the MAGA agenda to New Jersey. We aren’t going to let that happen. We cannot allow that to happen in this great state of New Jersey. Mikie has one of the strongest records in this country when it comes to defending reproductive rights. She has fought against Washington extremists who are trying to push a nationwide abortion ban. She doesn’t just talk the talk — she leads with action. And that’s what we need in our next governor,” said Assemblywoman Carmen Morales.

As governor, Mikie will work to enshrine abortion rights into our state constitution, stockpile the abortion pill, Mifepristone, and strengthen protections for providers.  

Mikie is a lead sponsor of legislation to affirm that the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act includes access to emergency abortion care, and is pushing for legislation that would stop Washington Republicans from using the Comstock Act to attack abortion access nationwide. Mikie is also the leading voice in Congress to ban the practice of “judge shopping” — which anti-abortion advocates have used to ensure favorable court decisions, and is fighting to protect access to reproductive health care by codifying the Department of Defense travel policy that allows servicewomen to travel for reproductive care.

data.title: Health Care Costs
data.description:
New Jersey is home to a world-class health care industry, but for many families, that comes with a staggering price tag. In Congress, I helped pass federal legislation that helped dramatically lower the cost of health care for seniors, including capping the cost of insulin at $35 a month — and capping senior's out-of-pocket prescription drug spending at $2,000 annually. New Jersey has taken the right steps, followed suit, and extended the Inflation Reduction Act's insulin cap to GetCoveredNJ, as well as public employee benefits plans. But we must do more, and as governor, I will direct the state to identify promising avenues for patient savings on prescription drugs.

Simply receiving quality care should never break the bank. A critical piece to addressing skyrocketing costs is greater transparency in health care pricing. With all other major financial decisions, like buying a home, people know what they will be paying upfront. But in health care, patients often don't know the price tag until they receive the bill. For patients who have the ability to shop around for affordable care in advance, increased competition will bring prices down. Keeping health care costs under control will ensure everyone in New Jersey can access the care they need without falling into medical debt.

Read more about Mikie’s Affordability Agenda, and how it will bring down health care costs.

data.title: Assemblywoman Eliana Pintor Marin Makes Official Endorsement of Mikie Sherrill for Governor
data.description:
NEWARK — Assemblywoman Eliana Pintor Marin (LD-29) announced her formal endorsement of Mikie Sherrill for Governor. Assemblywoman Pintor Marin and  Mikie Sherrill have worked together throughout her campaign to connect with voters in Newark and throughout the Portuguese community.

“Here in New Jersey, we need a decisive leader who is going to roll up her sleeves and get right to work tackling the biggest issues facing New Jersey families. I know that is exactly what Mikie will do as our next governor, because we are both committed mothers and committed public servants. From the rising cost of housing, utilities, and groceries, to the challenges we face keeping our children safe on social media, Mikie has a vision and plan to get the job done in Trenton. I am so proud to endorse her because I know that she values hard work, is deeply committed to serving our state and our country, and wants to build opportunities for all of our children. Join me in getting out and casting your ballot for the next governor, Mikie Sherrill!” said Assemblywoman Eliana Pintor Marin.

“Throughout this campaign, I have been excited to work with Assemblywoman Pintor Marin as we listen to residents in Newark and connect on the issues that matter most to working families, whether that’s stronger support for small businesses or bringing down everyday costs for families. That’s why I am truly honored to earn her endorsement. As the State Assembly Budget chair, Eliana is the type of excellent partner I need in Trenton to lower costs and expand opportunities for families to thrive here in the Garden State,” said Mikie Sherrill.

Mikie Sherrill has earned broad support from community leaders in the City of Newark because of her clear vision to lower costs for families and her commitment to serving communities across the entire state. She has also earned the support of additional Portuguese community leaders like Retired Essex County Sheriff Armando Fontoura. Earlier this week, she was endorsed by Senate Majority Leader Teresa Ruiz and has also been endorsed by the Payne family.
 
 

Deputada Eliana Pintor Marin Oficialmente Apoia Mikie Sherrill Para Ser Governadora 
 

NEWARK — Deputada Eliana Pintor Marin (LD-29) anunciou seu apoio formal de Mikie Sherrill para ser Governadora. A deputada Pintor Marin e Mikie Sherrill têm trabalhado juntos durante a campanha inteira para fazer conexões com os votantes de Newark e a comunidade Portuguesa inteira. 

“Aqui em New Jersey, precisamos de um líder forte quem vai trabalhar para solucionar os problemas maiores que enfrentam as famílias de New Jersey. Sei que isso é exatamente o que Mikie fará como nossa próxima governadora, porque nós somos mães e servidores públicos comprometidas. Desde o alto custo de hogares, serviços públicos, e comida, até as dificuldades de manter a segurança de nossas crianças nas redes sociais, Mikie tem uma visão e uma agenda para entregar resultados em Trenton. Estou bem orgulhosa de apoiá-la, porque sei que ela valoriza o trabalho duro, está comprometida a servir o nosso estado e nosso país, e quer criar oportunidades para todas nossas crianças.  Une-se comigo para votar para a próxima governadora, Mikie Sherrill!” disse Deputada Eliana Pintor Marin.

“Durante essa campanha inteira, tenho estado entusiasmada para trabalhar com a Deputada Pintor Marin enquanto escutamos os residentes de Newark e falamos sobre os problemas mais importantes para as famílias trabalhadoras, seja o apoio mais forte para as empresas pequenas ou baixando custos diários para famílias.  Por isso, estou realmente honrada por ter recebido seu apoio. Como presidente do Comitê do Orçamento da Assembleia, Eliana é o tipo de parceira excelente que preciso em Trenton para baixar custos e expandir oportunidades para que as famílias possam prosperar aqui no Estado Jardim,” disse Mikie Sherrill. 

Mikie Sherrill recebeu amplo apoio dos líderes da comunidade na Cidade de Newark como resultado da sua visão clara para baixar custos para famílias e seu compromisso de servir comunidades no estado inteiro. Também recebeu apoio de outros líderes na comunidade Portuguesa, como o antigo Xerife de Essex County Armando Fontoura. No início desta semana, ela foi apoiada pela Líder de Maioria no Senado, Teresa Ruiz, e também foi apoiada pela família Payne.

data.title: Mikie Meets with Chambers of Commerce Across New Jersey, Outlines Her Plan to Grow Jobs, Lower Costs for Businesses, and Boost Transit Investment
data.description:
BLOOMFIELD — Mikie Sherrill met with the Atlantic, Burlington, and Hudson County Chambers of Commerce to share her plans to make it easier to start and grow a business in New Jersey, and to boost innovation and economic growth in the Garden State through investments in transit, workforce development, and child care.
 
“Trenton isn’t working for families and businesses across our state. Whether it’s waiting months for basic permits or paying thousands just to fill out duplicate forms, our state agencies are plagued by a culture of ‘no,’ rather than getting to ‘yes.’ As governor, I will drive a culture shift in Trenton that is focused on customer service, transparency, and accountability front and center. Lowering costs will be the number one priority for my administration. That’s why, on day one, I will declare a State of Emergency on Utility Costs. I’ll take on anyone — including my own party — to get things done for New Jersey, unlike my opponent who won’t take on anyone, because he’s focused on serving Trump,” said Mikie Sherrill. 

“Mikie understands the critical urgency of investing in Hudson County’s transit network and business community, which is essential for New Jersey’s economy to take full advantage of next year’s World Cup. She also has a comprehensive plan to make it easier to start and grow a business in Hudson County and throughout the state, by slashing wait times for business licenses, creating enforceable and accountable permitting deadlines at our state agencies, and reducing fees on new businesses that are just starting up. I look forward to working with her as a partner to grow businesses and create good-paying jobs in Hudson County,” said Stacy Gemma, member of the Hudson County Chamber of Commerce Board of Directors and Sales Associate at Donovan Realty and Development.

At the Atlantic City Chamber of Commerce, Mikie outlined her plans to support fair investments in Atlantic City and expand the workforce in key industries in the region, like gaming and agriculture.

Mikie shared her long track record of supporting Joint Base McGuire-Dix-Lakehurst at the Burlington County Chamber of Commerce and talked about her plans to invest in bus rapid transit, microtransit, and child care to boost South Jersey’s economy.

Mikie addressed the Hudson County Chamber’s concerns about ensuring that Hudson County can reap the economic benefits of hosting the 2026 FIFA World Cup and her plans to fix the PATH system and NJ TRANSIT to improve reliability for commuters and reduce congestion.

data.title: Mikie Sherrill wants to be the transit, housing, and transparency-obsessed governor
data.description:
By Joey Fox, New Jersey Globe

After months – years, even – of planning and speculation, Rep. Mikie Sherrill (D-Montclair) has at last entered the 2025 race for governor of New Jersey. She says she has a clear plan for what she wants to do if she wins.

Speaking with the New Jersey Globe this morning, Sherrill homed in on three issues that she plans on making her top priorities as governor: lowering housing costs, improving public transit, and increasing transparency in a state known for its shady politics. And she said that unlike other politicians, who remained unnamed but who may include some of her opponents for the governor’s office, she’s committed to actually doing what needs to be done.

“We know that for too many people, they just don’t feel like they have access to the opportunity in this state. It’s too hard to get ahead,” Sherrill said. “People are worried that their rights and freedoms are under attack. And so I think we need real leadership in Trenton – not just somebody who’s going to talk about the problem, but actually deliver.”

Sherrill, a former U.S. Navy helicopter pilot and federal prosecutor, was first elected to represent the 11th congressional district in 2018, flipping a suburban North Jersey seat that had been held by Republicans for more than 30 years. Her victory that year was one of four Democratic flips in New Jersey that helped Democrats retake control of the House.

In the six years since then, Sherrill has established a record as a moderate Democrat with a particular focus on abortion rights and national security. But as she seeks to lead a state that already has strong abortion protections in place and where many voters care more about affordability problems than about international politics, the issues driving her gubernatorial campaign look a bit different.

The first policy priority Sherrill identified was housing, which she said is too expensive for many New Jerseyans and is pushing both younger and older people out of the state. While New Jersey in theory has strong affordable housing requirements thanks to the state Supreme Court, Sherrill said that the state needs to work on building “missing middle” housing for the middle class, repurposing office spaces and brownfields and incentivizing developers to build more than just luxury apartments.

“People like me, with kids, we want our kids moving back here,” she said. “When our kids are ready to start their family, we want them to be able to afford homes nearby. We don’t want them moving out of the state. When our parents retire, we don’t want them headed to Delaware or Florida. We want them here. And those types of options just aren’t available in too many places in New Jersey.”

Transit, too, is a key part of the congresswoman’s plan for the state. Sherrill has frequently dubbed herself the “tunnel-obsessed congresswoman,” referencing the Gateway Tunnel project that should make train service in and out of New York City much smoother once it’s completed, and she said that she’ll be just as obsessed with fixing New Jersey Transit, which has been through a rough year thanks to funding gaps and broader Amtrak issues.

Asked how she would work to fix the struggling agency – a task which has eluded current Gov. Phil Murphy and many governors before him – Sherrill said it would take a combination of better allocation of resources in New Jersey and more money coming in from Washington.

“We’ve got a $56 billion budget; we have got to take a look at that and make sure that we are spending money wisely on those things that are going to make life easier for families here,” she said. “But some of this has to be federally funded. When you look at the fact that the Amtrak rail line, which New Jersey Transit rents from Amtrak, has been under-maintained for years now – we need federal dollars in there.”

Sherrill’s emphasis on transit and housing puts her in league with Jersey City Mayor Steve Fulop, another 2025 candidate who has made those issues a centerpiece of his policy-heavy campaign. Sherrill’s colleague, Rep. Josh Gottheimer (D-Tenafly), has also focused strongly on affordability, though his immediate priorities (lowering taxes and clawing back the money New Jersey sends to the federal government) look a bit different.

Asked whether there was anything where she specifically disagreed with the current administration in Trenton, Sherrill said that she believed the state has not done enough to foster transparency and increase voters’ trust in government. She cited the Elections Transparency Act, a controversial campaign finance overhaul from 2023, and an even more controversial 2024 bill that weakened some parts of the Open Public Records Act, both of which were signed into law by Murphy.

“We’ve had a series of corruption scandals,” Sherrill said. “Our state is sadly somewhat known for that in certain quarters. So voters have demanded, and the people of New Jersey deserve, transparency and accountability. I would disagree with certain measures that have been taken to undermine some of those ways in which we provide that to people.”

Sherrill is, in some ways, an unlikely messenger for that fight. She is closely entwined with many of the Democratic leaders who were instrumental in pushing for the bills she’s criticized; the leader of the state Democratic Party, Essex County Democratic Chair LeRoy Jones, is preparing to support her campaign for governor.

But Sherrill said that no matter who is backing her, she’ll always answer to the voters of New Jersey first and foremost.

“The number one group that I want to get support from is the people of New Jersey,” she said. “I really want voters to support this campaign because they believe in what I’m doing. To do that, I’m going to build a broad based campaign that includes everyone. And that’s really what I’ve always done.”

data.title: Mikie Qualifies for Matching Funds with $600K Fundraising Haul After First Day in Governor's Race
data.description:
WEST CALDWELL — As of the first 24 hours since launching her campaign, Mikie Sherrill raised more than $600,000 with Democrats across New Jersey rallying around her vision for a different type of leadership and a fresh perspective in Trenton. This historic raise allows the campaign to qualify for matching funds under New Jersey’s public financing program. 

“Mikie is bringing something different to this campaign — a new type of leadership for New Jersey, forged through nearly 10 years in the U.S. Navy, and a fresh perspective to achieve big things for the people of this state. The enthusiasm and support for Mikie’s vision has been exciting and encouraging as she introduces herself to New Jersey voters and travels across the state to hear both their concerns and aspirations for our future,” said spokesperson Sean Higgins.

On top of her massive fundraising haul, Mikie also earned endorsements on Monday from the New Jersey Firefighters Mutual Benevolent Association (FMBA), the state’s most prominent firefighters union, and EMILYs List, the nation’s largest organization dedicated to electing more pro-choice Democratic women to office.

Today, on the second day of the campaign, Mikie is on the road to hear from New Jerseyans about the issues that matter most and what they want for our future. She will stop by Eva’s Village in Paterson to visit with New Jerseyans in need along with Paterson Mayor Andre Sayegh. Then, she will visit with LiUNA members working at the Rutgers Cancer Institute construction project in New Brunswick. Next, she will speak with patients and providers at the Visiting Nurses Association’s (VNA) Red Bank Community Health Center. Finally, the tour will end in Atlantic City with the New Jersey FMBA — the state’s largest firefighters union.

You can watch Mikie’s announcement video — “Build Something” — by clicking here.

data.title: EMILY's List endorses Rep. Mikie Sherrill in race for New Jersey governor
data.description:
EMILY’s List, a national group that backs Democratic women running for office, endorsed Rep. Mikie Sherrill’s bid for New Jersey governor on Monday, just hours after she announced her campaign.

In a statement shared first with NBC News, EMILY’s List President Jessica Mackler highlighted Sherrill’s military service and her time in Congress, adding that the group hopes she’ll become the first Democratic woman to serve as governor in the Garden State.

“In the United States Navy and in Congress, Rep. Sherrill has shown her unwavering commitment to serving our country and the people of New Jersey. Her record passing bipartisan legislation to bring down health care costs, lower taxes for New Jersey residents, and fight for our reproductive rights is clear. We are thrilled to support Rep. Sherrill and to elect the first Democratic woman governor of New Jersey,” Mackler said.

Sherrill, a former Navy helicopter commander and former federal prosecutor who flipped a Republican-held seat in 2018, is joining an already crowded Democratic field.

Just last week, fellow Rep. Josh Gottheimer announced his bid for governor, and Newark Mayor Ras Baraka and Jersey City Mayor Steve Fulop are also running.

The race, one of just two gubernatorial elections slated for 2025, is expected to draw lots of attention and spending. Gov. Phil Murphy, a Democrat, is term-limited and not able to run for re-election, leaving an opening for eager Democrats looking to take over the governor’s mansion.

All eyes will be on this race and the race to succeed Virginia GOP Gov. Glenn Youngkin next year, as these off-year elections are often seen as indicators of how voters are reacting to the first year of a new presidential administration.

Sherrill is the first woman to enter the New Jersey race. EMILY’s List has also endorsed Rep. Abigail Spanberger, D-Va., who is running in Virginia’s gubernatorial contest.

The organization has previously supported the congressional campaigns of both women.

data.title: ICYMI: CWA District 1 Endorses Mikie Sherrill for Governor of New Jersey
data.description:
TRENTON — The Communications Workers of America (CWA), District 1, proudly announced its endorsement of Congresswoman Mikie Sherrill in her campaign for Governor of New Jersey. CWA members across the Garden State — from state and local government to healthcare, telecommunications, and beyond — will mobilize to support Sherrill’s campaign, citing her proven leadership and steadfast commitment to working families and our communities.

CWA District 1 Vice President Dennis G. Trainor issued the following statement of endorsement:

“New Jersey’s working families need a fighter - and Mikie Sherrill is exactly the kind of leader we need right now. Mikie has built her career on service, leadership, and delivering results—from her time as a federal prosecutor to her work as a U.S. Representative. In Congress, Rep. Sherrill has been a steadfast advocate for labor rights, affordable healthcare, and strong public infrastructure. With a 100% lifetime voting record, we know that she stands with us on our issues, from fighting for union rights to supporting critical investments in public services. Never one to back down from a fight, we know that Mikie will continue to stand up for workers as Governor. In times like these, we need a  Governor who won’t just talk about supporting workers, but who will stand up and fight alongside us. We need someone who understands that strong unions, fair contracts, affordable healthcare and public investment are key to rebuilding an economy that works for everyone. CWA members across New Jersey will be working around the clock to talk to their friends, neighbors and co-workers about what’s at stake in the election and the importance of electing a Governor who supports CWA’s mission to build power for working people.”

This election comes at a pivotal time. Right now, unions are facing unprecedented attacks; corporations and politicians are working overtime to weaken union rights, strip away bargaining power, and silence unions’ voices. At the same time, working families are being crushed by an affordability crisis—rising healthcare costs, housing prices, and everyday expenses are outpacing wages and pushing people to the brink. 

Right now, CWA is campaigning tirelessly to address the crushing rise in healthcare costs working families in New Jersey are facing. The issue of uncontrolled healthcare costs in the public sector and the devastating impact it’s having on working New Jerseyans is urgent and requires action. Mikie Sherrill has committed to addressing the healthcare affordability crisis once she’s elected as New Jersey’s next Governor in November. 

“I’m proud to receive the endorsement of CWA District 1 and its members. CWA is a powerhouse that fearlessly fights for key issues like job security, healthcare and union rights — and I’m proud to stand with them. As Governor, I will tackle the healthcare affordability crisis head on, protect the right to organize, and invest in the public services that working people depend on every day. Together, we’ll build a New Jersey that works for working families,” said Rep. Mikie Sherrill.

The Communications Workers of America represents working people in public service, telecommunications, customer service, media, airlines, healthcare, and education, manufacturing, tech, and other fields. CWA represents roughly 75,000 public sector workers throughout New Jersey.

data.title: Mikie Sherrill and Senator Andy Kim Hear Directly from New Jerseyans in Paterson about Trump’s Cuts to Health Care and Food Assistance
data.description:
PATERSON — Today, Mikie Sherrill and Senator Andy Kim visited Eva’s Village in Paterson to hear about the most pressing issues facing the community and the residents they serve — and how Trump’s cuts to Medicaid, Medicare, and food assistance will be devastating for families across the state. This stands in stark contrast to Jack Ciattarelli, who has consistently supported these cuts — and again, yesterday, couldn’t name a single issue on which he disagreed with Trump. 

“On the first day of my campaign, I stopped at Eva’s Village and heard from New Jerseyans who were struggling to find safe and affordable health care and housing. Today, I went back alongside Senator Andy Kim, where we heard from New Jerseyans about how Donald Trump and his lackey Jack Ciattarelli are going to make it so much harder to get ahead by cutting health care and food assistance. New Jersey needs real leadership, not a follower who will do whatever Trump tells him to do. That’s why I’m running — to break through the status quo in Trenton so every family can afford to live, work, and thrive here in the Garden State,” said Mikie Sherrill.

“Leaders listen, and Mikie’s commitment to servant leadership was clear today as we sat down with clients and leadership at Eva’s Village to hear about the issues that keep them up at night. We heard from New Jerseyans struggling to afford a safe place to live, to find quality health care, and to put food on the table. In Congress, I’ve seen how Mikie takes what she hears in the community and delivers real results. I know she’ll bring that same work ethic to Trenton, unlike Jack Ciattarelli, who is running in lock step with Donald Trump to serve himself,” said Senator Andy Kim. 

Donald Trump’s “Big Beautiful Bill” will have disastrous consequences for New Jersey families. His proposed cuts to Medicaid, the Affordable Care Act, and SNAP would take health care coverage away from 410,000 New Jerseyans and slash the food assistance that helps 185,000 Garden State residents afford groceries. This legislation will strip significant federal funding from hospitals across New Jersey and impose almost $1 billion in new costs onto them, while cutting access to essential substance abuse treatment and mental health care programs. It will also cause utility and mortgage rates to increase across New Jersey and leave a multi-billion dollar hole in the state budget — just so Trump can give tax breaks to the wealthiest Americans and stick working families with the bill.

Despite the punishing impact this bill will have on New Jersey families, Jack Ciattarelli has consistently supported it, in lock-step with Trump, saying, “Shame on any Republican across the country that doesn't support this.” He has deflected questions by saying cuts to Medicaid — which provides health coverage for nearly 2 million New Jerseyans — and education programs that support our schools and students are not New Jersey issues, blindly unaware of the budget impact on the State of New Jersey. Ciattarelli even said, “We don't see this as a real problem in New Jersey. I think it's all going to work out just fine.”

Let’s not forget, Ciattarelli made millions peddling misinformation about opioids into our communities, leading to an addiction crisis. Now, he’s standing by as Trump cuts access to critical addiction and mental health treatment services.

data.title: ICYMI: Washington Post Highlights Mikie Sherrill’s Leadership in 2025 Race for Governor
data.description:
“Sherrill’s campaign focuses on the day-to-day needs of New Jerseyans” 
 
BLOOMFIELD — In case you missed it, a column in the Washington Post highlighted the different type of leadership Mikie Sherrill would bring to Trenton as Governor of New Jersey. In an interview, Mikie spoke about her experience in the U.S. Navy and as a former Assistant U.S. Attorney, and her relentless focus on the day-to-day needs of New Jersey residents — from housing to transit. You can read more excerpts below: 

Washington Post: Sherrill’s run for governor: ‘Lead, follow or get out of the way’
By Jennifer Rubin 

  • Rep. Mikie Sherrill — a former Navy helicopter pilot and federal prosecutor reelected this year to her fourth House term — does not suffer do-nothing, self-promoting politicians (who dominate Washington politics) lightly. “I think there are so many issues that too many people have used as partisan ideological campaign-winning tools and not actually looked to really address and to serve people,” she told me during an interview last week in D.C. “Some of the people that are most ideological seem to me to be people that are most self-serving because they want to create this sort of pure partisanship.”

  • Given her impressive background and the partisan quagmire on Capitol Hill, it is hardly surprising, then, that Sherrill has declared her run for governor in New Jersey, one of the few major 2025 races. In a crowded Democratic field to replace term-limited Democratic Gov. Phil Murphy, she stands out as the only woman (earning her an endorsement from Emily’s List) — and the one who exudes a healthy impatience with politicians “more focused on their own political agenda than actual public service.”

  • Her military and legal background have fostered a take-charge attitude. “If you’re going to deal with a crisis moment, you have to make decisions and you have to lead, you cannot sit idly by and hope it passes over,” she said. “Too many people in elected office” don’t want to “stick their head up.”

  • Sherrill said she prefers the approach learned in the Navy: “It’s just lead, follow or get out of the way. If you don’t want to be leading, then don’t be in a leadership position.”

  • New Jersey politics can be a rough-and-tumble affair, one in which pugnacious, confrontational men, such as Republican former governor Chris Christie, have dominated. But Sherrill, a mother of four, combines her decisiveness with an engaging, down-to-earth personality. In some ways, she embodies the profile of a suburban, professional mom — the busiest one, who you know will get things done — familiar in her state.

  • Sherrill’s campaign focuses on the day-to-day needs of New Jerseyans. She pointed to “some of the underlying issues,” such as the housing shortage, and affordability, or “the New Jersey Transit system, which is crumbling.” She understands challenges such as holding down carbon emissions while ensuring enough power supply, and wants New Jersey to remain “an innovative state that cares about rights and freedoms, but also needs to deliver on those brass tacks economic issues.”

data.title: Opinion: Can these Capitol Hill roommates lead Democrats out of the wilderness?
data.description:
By Karen Tumulty, The Washington Post

If the future of the Democratic Party hinges on its candidates connecting better with the pressures that average Americans are feeling, there might be no greater hope for the losing side at this moment than Abigail Spanberger of Virginia and Mikie Sherrill of New Jersey.

The two congresswomen, both moderates, have shared a Capitol Hill apartment for the past four years, eating frozen entrées from Trader Joe’s and balancing their work as legislators with their roles as busy moms.

Both came to Washington with impressive credentials in high-pressure national security jobs — Annapolis grad Sherrill was a Navy helicopter pilot; Spanberger was an undercover CIA officer — and each had won in a district that hadn’t sent a Democrat to the House in decades.

They even look somewhat alike, though Spanberger’s hair is a few shades blonder; they have been mistaken for one another by constituents visiting the Capitol and even by some of their House colleagues. During a conversation I had with them in September, they sometimes finished each other’s sentences.

And now, they have something else in common: The two women are strong contenders to be the next governors of Virginia and New Jersey. Their races in 2025 will show how well Democrats are heeding the lessons of 2024.

Sherrill, 52, who remains a House member, announced her bid for governor on Monday. “Everyone here knows the opportunity that New Jersey affords, but nobody can afford New Jersey,” she told me. “Whether they’re making $50,000 year or $150,000 a year or more, it just feels like they’re not able to get ahead. They’re not able to get to stable ground. That’s why I’m running for governor, because I truly and deeply believe that well-run, efficient government can deliver for people.”

Early polls suggest the only woman on either side in that race so far starts at or near the front of the pack. Still, New Jersey politics are known for being wild, and Sherrill will be competing in a crowded primary to replace term-limited Democratic Gov. Phil Murphy.

Spanberger, 45, who did not seek reelection to her Virginia House seat, is proving such a formidable contender for governor that she faces no opposition in the Democratic primary.

Her Republican opponent is all but certain to be Lt. Gov. Winsome Earle-Sears, a Marine veteran whose 2021 campaign posters featured her holding an assault-style rifle. Which means that a commonwealth where past governors have included Thomas Jefferson and James Monroe, but never a woman, will probably be choosing between two of them next year.

The contests that Virginia and New Jersey hold the year after presidential elections have long been early indicators of how the political landscape is shifting ahead of the midterm elections. More often than not, they swing against the president’s party.

But these two races might also validate a broader movement in the electorate: This year, Vice President Kamala Harris carried both Virginia and New Jersey, as expected, but her margins over Donald Trump were only about half what Joe Biden’s had been four years before.

Spanberger certainly seems to understand voters’ volatile mood. “I’m going to continue talking about the things I hear most about from voters, and that’s, frankly, lowering costs. It’s strengthening our public schools. It’s keeping our communities safe. It’s protecting our rights, particularly in Virginia, the last state in the South that hasn’t seen further restrictions on abortion rights since Dobbs,” she said, referring to the 2022 Supreme Court decision that overturned Roe v. Wade.

But a new set of concerns might matter in a purplish state that is home to vast numbers of federal workers and contractors who could be decimated by Trump’s plan for a top-to-bottom overhaul of Washington. “I will, both as a candidate and ultimately as a governor, have to be able to respond along the way to ensure that Virginia is doing everything to protect people, their livelihood, our economy and their health,” Spanberger said.

When Sherrill and Spanberger arrived in Washington in 2019, each rented an apartment on the same floor of a building near the Capitol.

“Some people seem to have fun in Congress. Speaking for both of us, while we’re here, we’re away from our families. We just work from the time we get up to the time we go to bed, and it’s meeting, meeting, meeting,” Spanberger said.

What’s more, she added, it was lonely to begin and end each day in a rented apartment where “the only sound is your own.”

So they asked one another: Why not move in together?

The apartment they have shared Mondays through Thursdays when Congress is in session was no palace when they moved in. They sat on a stained 20-year-old living room couch that Spanberger dragged out of storage. Dinners together were eaten off Sherrill’s gold-rimmed wedding china, which — inconveniently — couldn’t go in the microwave.

To occupy what little free time they had, they drank a lot of coffee, occasionally took a sauna and resolved to make more visits to the gym. The mention of that last one brought a burst of laughter. “Aspirational,” both of them admitted.

Discovering how the House operated — and didn’t — quickly became a source of shared frustration. The 116th U.S. Congress had an unusually large number of freshmen, 19 in all, who came to the job with backgrounds in national security. They had won in districts where Democrats typically didn’t, and, it was hoped, they would be an antidote to partisanship and gridlock. Five of them were women, who christened themselves “the Badasses.”

“All of us were sort of predisposed to working together on a mission,” Sherrill said. “In the military, you’re not like, oh, are you a Democrat or Republican? Or did you come from New Jersey or from Alabama? You work with people from all over the country, all different backgrounds, but you all share the mission focus.”

Congress, however, was not built that way. It moves slowly, when it moves at all, and members rarely step outside their partisan and ideological lanes. “We were like, ‘What’s the strategy? Where’s the strategy?’” Spanberger said. “There’s just an urgency problem: What’s the problem? Identify the problem. What are the risks? How do we move? Let’s move."

When they stood together, though, they could get results. It was their voices in September 2019 that led to Trump’s first impeachment. The issue was the president’s attempt to coerce Ukraine’s newly elected leader, Volodymyr Zelensky, into investigating Joe Biden by holding back nearly $400 million in military aid to the country.

Trump had been accused of other misdeeds. But the moderate, national security-minded freshmen hadn’t been convinced that those uncovered in special counsel Robert S. Mueller III’s investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election rose to the Constitution’s “high crimes and misdemeanors” standard for impeachment.

To them, refusing badly needed weapons to Ukraine clearly did. “We saw he was withholding those because he wanted Zelensky to dig up and manufacture evidence against Biden, who he thought was going to be his opponent in a democratic election. Finally, we all said that is a bright line,” Sherrill recalled.

The Badasses, plus two of their male freshman colleagues, wrote a powerful Post op-ed, in which they argued: “We have devoted our lives to the service and security of our country, and throughout our careers, we have sworn oaths to defend the Constitution of the United States many times over. Now, we join as a unified group to uphold that oath as we enter uncharted waters and face unprecedented allegations against President Trump.”

More-progressive House members representing safe districts had already been arguing to impeach Trump. That these seven freshmen were willing to put their political careers on the line and join them persuaded then-Speaker Nancy Pelosi (California) to end her own resistance to taking such a dramatic step against a sitting president. Within 24 hours of their op-ed being published, Pelosi announced the opening of an official impeachment inquiry against Trump.

What they saw nationally and what they experienced within their own families during the covid-19 pandemic brought another turning point for Spanberger and Sherrill, convincing both they could make a bigger difference by returning to their home states.

Densely populated New Jersey was one of the earliest and hardest-hit states, Sherrill noted. Congress did vital work during the pandemic, she said, providing money “to keep people connected to their small businesses and to keep people employed and to keep people getting paychecks to be able to buy food.”

“But it wasn’t the same as delivering PPE gear to hospitals or being able to institute the Defense Production Act and get the manufacturing base engaged in a crisis to deliver for people. It wasn’t the power that an executive would have in that instance,” she explained. “Seeing what governors across the country have been doing, and how Washington has become so partisan and toxic ... I just feel that often the future of how we really deliver for people, or the effectiveness of how we can deliver for people, resides in these governors across the country.”

The two women also felt the impact as mothers whose children — Sherrill has four; Spanberger has three — are still showing the effects of school shutdowns. They told me about their anxieties for a daughter who spent kindergarten and first grade in front of a computer screen and still hasn’t learned to read as she should; the middle-schooler who doesn’t want to have friends over. They recalled the sheer ridiculousness of watching a son put together empty paper towel rolls and call it an art project. And theirs, they stressed, are kids who have had every privilege.

“I don’t think people without school-age kids understand what covid has done to our children,” Sherrill said. “A lot of us lost all ability to monitor screen time in our children because their entire life was online. And now we come out of the other side of covid, and we’re having a second trauma of all of the algorithms and what kids are seeing online and all of their social media profiles.”

Still, for all the advantages Spanberger and Sherrill have, winning executive office has always been a harder lift for female candidates than winning legislative office. Research has shown voters are more willing to accept women in collaborative roles than as the chief decider. For many disappointed Democrats, Harris’s defeat only confirmed it.

But the good news is, there are a dozen women — a record — serving as governors.

Barring a surprise, Virginia will add to that number, and the fact that the leading candidates for both parties there are female, Spanberger knows, will be both thrilling and a political challenge in itself. “What’s going to be interesting is, I do think that there will be much made of the fact that it’s two women, and one of them will be the first woman governor in Virginia,” she said. “It will be incumbent upon me to make sure that people are clear-eyed about what the actual policy differences are.”

Garden State politics, meanwhile, have traditionally run on testosterone and cronyism. Its only female governor was a Republican, Christine Todd Whitman.

“I’d say that after serving in the military for years, especially at a time when women serving in the military was somewhat unusual and they were breaking through barriers — that kind of grit and determination, I think, has served me well as I’ve entered into the rough-and-tumble world of New Jersey politics,” Sherrill said.

There is a lot of despair, in the wake of their 2024 defeat up and down the ballot, that Democrats have lost their way. But the thing about elections is, there’s always another one on the horizon. Coming back will require a new model of leadership. Which is why these two roommates are worth watching.

data.title: New Jersey AFL-CIO Unites Behind Mikie Sherrill for Governor
data.description:
Endorsement Represents Over 1 Million Union Members and Their Families 
 

ATLANTIC CITY, NJ – The New Jersey State AFL-CIO today announced its endorsement of Congresswoman Mikie Sherrill for Governor of New Jersey, citing her strong record of public service, her deep commitment to working families, and her unwavering support for organized labor. 

“Congresswoman Mikie Sherrill has always stood shoulder-to-shoulder with New Jersey’s working people,” said Charles Wowkanech, President of the New Jersey State AFL-CIO. “She understands the dignity of work, the importance of strong unions, and the role that labor plays in building a fair  economy. As our next Governor, she’ll fight for quality and accessible health care for every family, for great public schools for every kid, and to make New Jersey more affordable for everyone.” 

“With a 100% voting record with labor, Mikie has fought for us in Washington, and we are proud to fight for her now. She’s the leader New Jersey’s labor movement trusts to champion workers' rights and deliver for all our families.” 

The endorsement was unanimous and made by 500 delegates representing every sector of the labor movement and over one million union members and their families across New Jersey. 

“From protecting collective bargaining rights to expanding access to apprenticeship programs, Mikie Sherrill has shown that she doesn’t just listen to workers — she acts,” added Laurel Brennan, Secretary Treasurer of the New Jersey State AFL-CIO. “She knows that when workers succeed, New Jersey succeeds. We are proud to endorse her campaign and will mobilize our members across the state to help ensure she becomes our next Governor.” 

With more than a thousand affiliated local unions, the New Jersey State AFL-CIO represents a powerful coalition of public and private-sector workers across the state. Today’s endorsement sends a clear signal that labor is unified and energized heading into the November election. 

“I’m honored to have the support of the New Jersey State AFL-CIO, because there couldn’t be more at stake in this gubernatorial election,” said Congresswoman Sherrill. “Our state is stronger because of the power of organized labor and I will always have your back in Trenton. As governor, I will never stop fighting for the dignity, safety, and well-being of every worker in New Jersey.”

data.title: Piloting NJ through the Trump era: Why Mikie Sherrill is running for governor
data.description:
By Julie O'Connor, Star-Ledger Editorial Board

From leading a Navy helicopter squadron, to New Jersey in the Trump era, Rep. Mikie Sherrill says she’s ready for action: On Monday, she officially declared her candidacy for governor.

She jumped into a pileup of candidates to succeed Phil Murphy, who is term limited. Her Democratic rivals include Rep. Josh Gottheimer, former Senate President Stephen Sweeney, Jersey City Mayor Steven Fulop, Newark Mayor Ras Baraka and Sean Spiller, head of the state’s largest teacher’s union.

Sherrill, a former pilot and federal prosecutor, has served in the House since 2018, when she flipped a red district that hadn’t voted for a Democrat since 1982. Now, in a packed field for governor, she’s the only woman running. Hours after announcing, she spoke with the editorial board about this latest mission. Below is a transcript, edited for brevity.

Q. This is a crowded field for Democrats. What sets you apart?

I bring a fresh perspective. I come from a background of service, from when I first started at the Naval Academy to when, by my early 20s, I was leading men and women in a helicopter squadron and missions around the world. This is what the military trains you for: To bring a diverse group of people together from all over the nation around a common goal.

I think that’s something that I’ve been able to bring to bear. I was told I couldn’t win my race in the 11th district of New Jersey when I ran in 2018, and really brought everyone together around those issues we all cared about and was able to have the largest swing from red to blue in the entire nation in that cycle, with a lot of seats flipping.

Then I was told that as a freshman member of Congress, I wouldn’t be able to get anything done and it would take a long time. And by my second term, I was named the most effective legislator in the House delegation by the Center for Effective Lawmaking. And despite the fact that we saw losses in a lot of the state in the recent election, in my district – even Morris County, the more traditionally Republican part – not only did we hold on to all the seats, but we were actually able to pick up a few more.

Q. You say we need to make life more affordable for New Jerseyans. How would you do that? Any ideas on the cost of housing, for example?

If you want to know what I would do in Trenton, take a look at my record, whether it’s getting fixes for the state and local tax deduction cap through the House twice, addressing grocery prices with a “Shrinkflation” bill, but also a bill to add competition into grocery stores and drive prices down; legislation to make sure no one pays more than 7% of their income on childcare, or the most recent legislation I’m working on to get federal funding to convert office parks or brownfield spaces to housing spaces, so we can address the housing shortage in our state.

Q. Do you think it’s possible to contain property taxes without taking on the public worker unions and cutting benefits for folks like cops and teachers, which are largely driving the increases?

Yeah. I think you’ve got to look at what we can do. I was just talking to one of the mayors in my district about the fact that all the firehouses have private mechanics that are hugely expensive for all their fire trucks, and couldn’t they share services? It’s looking for opportunities where we can drive costs down without cutting wages, through programs towns want to opt into to continue to have those things they most care about.

Q. Just on cuts to benefits: Is that something that you would look at?

You know, we have to make sure people who work hard have benefits at the end of their life. One of the things that was so impactful to my family is the fact that after they lost everything in the Great Depression, my grandfather went to fight in the war and then came home and got a good union job. He never made tons of money. My mom grew up in a very modest household. But at the end of his life, they had benefits, and when he and my grandma got sick, it didn’t bankrupt my family.

Q. The governor famously promised to fix NJ Transit even if it kills him. And by most accounts, he failed. As governor, what will you do differently?

I’ve already been working hard on that. This is a critical issue. I know this personally because my husband commutes almost every day, and I was commuting when my kids were little — that gut-churning anxiety you feel when you’re trying to get your kid at daycare, the scramble when somebody is late from work or can’t do pick up or drop off. This is the kind of upending of family life, quality of life, that people are experiencing. We’ve got to do more. And so I’ve been talking to NJ Transit, I’ve been talking to Amtrak. Over time Amtrak has just not been able to maintain the rail. They haven’t had enough resources from the federal government. We’ve got to push in there. That’s why I led the delegation advocating for federal funding for upgrades. Secretary Buttigieg just called to tell me that would be coming through, so now we have to apply for that grant money. The good news is, we have a long-term solution: The Gateway tunnel project is going to be a monumental change. The bad news is, it’s not going to be here next summer. So what are we going do in the meantime to make sure commuters have a much better experience?

Q. Should the new money raised for New Jersey Transit’s operations – the corporate transit fee – be permanent and dedicated to NJT? Would you extend it after it sunsets in five years?

Well first of all, that money has to go to New Jersey Transit. And the first year it did not, actually. The transit fee hasn’t actually gone to transit. So, I think it has to go to transit. I’d be happy to take a look.

Q. Switching topics, what do you think Kamala Harris’ tight win in New Jersey means? Is there a lesson here for the governor’s race? In our last gubernatorial race, Republicans nearly pulled off an upset.

I think the reason we held every seat in my district and even picked up a couple is because I’ve worked incredibly hard to maintain communications with people there, to constantly be checking in and figuring out, what is it that I can do and deliver to make life better? Whether it’s money for flooding, for innovation through the House Armed Services bill or to address PFAS, which are forever chemicals; or making sure we’re addressing car theft through driving money into the district for license plate readers – this stuff all comes directly from people in my district. Because of that, I think I saw really good results in this election, and can see really good results around the state.

Q. You say you want New Jersey to set the “gold standard” for protecting rights and freedoms threatened by Donald Trump. What rights do you think we need to solidify and how would you do that?

Obviously, we start with reproductive rights. But beyond that I’m worried about so much more. Trump has said he’s going to court martial admirals and generals because I think he wants to replace them with loyalists so he can co-opt the military. I worry about the Secretary of Defense pick he has, because that person has said that basically women shouldn’t be serving in many roles in our military, and I have a daughter in the military right now, and I know how hard-fought the gains women have made there have been. And I also know how effective the leadership of women has been, and how necessary when we’re fighting in places across the world and trying to win hearts and minds as we move forward on our goals. So, these things are all going to be critically important. And we’re continuing to see the attacks that Trump is envisioning from Washington. So, it’s about making sure people have this kind of access, that people are protected here. Democratic governors are going to be so key in this fight, and you can already see many coming up with a plan of action – especially those who were in office, as I was, in Trump’s last presidency.

Q. Any specific things NJ can do, that you’d focus on as governor?

Trenton initially took action to protect some of the early concerns we had when Roe was overturned. We need to continue to move forward on things like IVF, and making sure the way payment is structured for women seeking reproductive healthcare is more fair and equitable. The state also needs to start stockpiling some of the abortion medication, because I’m worried that if the Project 2025 plan comes to light, you’re going to see use of the Comstock Act in trying to prevent the mailing of some abortion pills. We also need to make sure we support reproductive health in our state constitution and embed it there. And we need to take a hard look at how we can, through our constitution and legislation, really protect freedoms we’re seeing coming under attack. As we see what type of things are coming from Washington, we need to be very ready to act in protection of people in the state of New Jersey.
