data.title: Mikie Sherrill kicks off gubernatorial campaign at Eva’s Village, tackling NJ’s housing crisis
data.description:
By Gabriella Dragone, TapInto Paterson

PATERSON, NJ - Just one day after announcing her candidacy for governor, Congresswoman Mikie Sherrill (NJ-11) made her first campaign stop at Eva’s Village in Paterson, to address New Jersey’s housing crisis. Sherrill, a former U.S. Navy helicopter commander, federal prosecutor, and mother of four, emphasized the need for innovative solutions to ensure affordable housing is accessible to all residents.

“Everywhere I go, I hear about housing challenges,” Sherrill said, addressing a group of residents and advocates. “People are being priced out of their homes, struggling with rising rents, or unable to find safe, affordable places to live. We need more housing in New Jersey, and we need to make it easier to access.”

Sherrill praised local efforts in Paterson, particularly Mayor André Sayegh’s innovative housing initiatives. The redevelopment of historic Hinchliffe Stadium has become a model project, officials say, combining senior affordable housing with housing for grandparents raising grandchildren. The city has also established housing for individuals with chronic medical conditions, with services that reduce emergency room dependency and provide long-term support.

Sayegh highlighted the importance of these initiatives, noting their role in addressing systemic issues in urban centers. 

“We’ve built housing for seniors, grandparents, and those struggling with homelessness and addiction. It’s a model that can and should be replicated across New Jersey,” he said. “Having Congresswoman Sherrill start her tour here reaffirms the significance of Paterson as not just a historical landmark, but a thriving city shaping the future of New Jersey.”

Residents shared their experiences with Sherrill, detailing the challenges of navigating bureaucratic red tape, finding employment with prior convictions, and accessing stable housing. Sherrill listened attentively, reflecting on her past work in the Navy and as a federal prosecutor, where she championed programs like prisoner re-entry initiatives and legislation to “ban the box” on job applications.

“I’ve seen how difficult it is for people to rebuild their lives after a setback,” Sherrill said. “Housing is foundational, but we also need wraparound services like those here at Eva’s Village—substance abuse recovery, job training, and financial counseling.”

Eva’s Village currently provides over 1,100 meals daily, transitional and permanent housing, and addiction recovery programs. Residents praised the organization’s focus on community and second chances. “Brotherhood and support have been critical to my recovery,” one participant shared.

Sherrill ended her visit by reiterating her commitment to tackling New Jersey’s housing crisis head-on.

“Paterson’s approach shows what’s possible when we innovate and prioritize people’s needs. As governor, I’ll make sure stories like yours shape the solutions we implement statewide.”

“As people run for higher offices, it’s easy to forget about those struggling with housing, substance abuse, or mental health issues," Sherrill added. ”I hear too little in the public discourse about real solutions for these challenges." 

"Yesterday, I announced my run for governor, and I want to make it clear: I’m not going to be the kind of governor who gives up on solving tough problems, and I know Andre [Sayegh] is not that kind of mayor. Mayor Andre Sayegh centers his work here in Paterson, our third-largest city, around innovative solutions. Coming here today, seeing an organization that started 40 years ago feeding people and has grown into so much more, was inspiring. Hearing the stories of the real impact it’s having on both sides of these issues highlights how much progress can be made when leaders don’t give up."

data.title: Mikie Sherrill Launches Campaign for New Jersey Governor
data.description:
WEST CALDWELL – Today, Mikie Sherrill — a former U.S. Navy helicopter aircraft commander, former federal prosecutor, U.S. Congresswoman, and mom of four — launched her campaign for governor, on a mission to get big things done for New Jersey. In her announcement video, Mikie shares how she will bring new leadership and a fresh perspective to New Jersey to build more housing, grow the economy, lower costs for families, and defend our freedoms. 

On Tuesday, she will hit the road to hear from New Jerseyans about the issues that matter most and what they want for our future. Her first stop will be Eva’s Village in Paterson to visit with New Jerseyans in need along with Mayor Andre Sayegh. Then, Mikie will meet with LiUNA members working at the Rutgers Cancer Institute construction project in New Brunswick. Next, she will speak with patients and providers at the Visiting Nurses Association’s (VNA) Red Bank Community Health Center. Finally, Tuesday’s tour will end in Atlantic City with the New Jersey Firefighters Mutual Benevolent Association — the state’s largest firefighters union.

You can watch Mikie’s announcement here and the script is below: 

We've been through a lot these past couple of years. 

There’ve been crises in this country, all over the world, and here in New Jersey.

And after this election, we know people are more divided than ever on how to move forward.

I'm Mikie Sherrill.

As a graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy and a former Navy helicopter aircraft commander, here's something I learned early on:

In a crisis, the worst thing you can do is freeze. 

You have to choose to lead, to follow, or get out of the way.

So we can either stand aside, or we can get to work on New Jersey's future.

And I know which one I pick. In New Jersey, we don't whine, we work.

Every time I pass that bridge in Trenton and see the sign, “Trenton Makes, The World Takes" — I think, "Hell yeah, that’s New Jersey."

This is the state, more than any other, that guaranteed our freedom as we fought for independence.

This is the state that built this nation. And while we were at it, we even invented the light bulb.

We've always been unafraid to do the big things — because we're inventors and innovators and builders. 

And we work with our minds and our hands.

So let's be the state that builds more housing, let's fix the economy, let's make life more affordable for hardworking New Jerseyans, from health care to groceries to childcare.

These challenges aren't new and it's time to confront them head on.

We can also be the state that sets the gold standard for protecting rights and freedoms, and we know they'll be under attack from Donald Trump's Washington.

Because in New Jersey, we love our country, we're proud of our state, and we value our freedoms.

We'll defend them with everything we've got.

In the Navy, I was on a mission to protect our country. 

Now, I'm announcing my candidacy for governor, on a mission to get things done for New Jersey.

This will be a campaign we build together because we all have a place and a say in New Jersey's future.

And I've met so many people who believe as deeply as I do in the promise of our state. And I'm asking you to join us.

So New Jersey, let's build something.

– 

Mikie Sherrill is a graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy and a former helicopter aircraft commander who served in the Navy for nearly 10 years. She worked as an Assistant U.S. Attorney to keep communities safe and get illegal guns off our streets. In her first-ever run for office, she led a grassroots movement and was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 2018. Her campaign — where she drove an entrenched Republican incumbent out of the race — marked the biggest swing from red to blue in the country that year. 

As a mother of four, Mikie is a strong voice in Congress for New Jersey families. Mikie is working hard to bring down costs — whether it’s grocery prices, child care, or Trump’s SALT cap that punished New Jerseyans. After constant roadblocks from the Christie and Trump administrations, Mikie helped deliver New Jersey’s fair share of federal funding on the Gateway Tunnel Project — the single-largest infrastructure project in American history, which will create good-paying union jobs and reduce commute times. She is fighting for reproductive freedom, defending abortion rights, as well as access to contraception and IVF. She sits on the House Armed Services Committee and the House Select Committee on the Chinese Communist Party. 

In 2023, Mikie was named the most effective New Jersey House lawmaker by the nonpartisan Center for Effective Lawmaking for her years of work delivering for Garden State residents. 

Mikie and her husband Jason, a fellow Naval Academy graduate, live in Montclair, New Jersey, and have four children. Her eldest daughter is currently serving in the U.S. Navy, following in her parents’ path of service. Mikie holds a Bachelor’s degree from the U.S. Naval Academy, a Master’s degree in Global History from the London School of Economics and Political Science, and a law degree from Georgetown University. 

###

data.title: Sherrill Wins Democratic Primary for New Jersey Gubernatorial Race
data.description:
Sherrill Defies Conventional Wisdom in New Jersey’s Most Competitive Gubernatorial Primary 

Sherrill Was Vastly Outspent, But Never Outworked 

Sherrill: “While Jack is for Trump, I am for New Jersey.”
 

BLOOMFIELD — Mikie Sherrill released the following statement today after winning the most competitive New Jersey gubernatorial primary in state history: 

“New Jersey showed the country tonight that we’re ready to chart a different path forward, and I am honored to be the Democratic nominee for governor of our great state. It’s time to bring a new generation of leadership to Trenton — and my experience not only in Congress, but as a Navy helicopter pilot for nearly 10 years, a federal prosecutor, and a mom raising four kids here in New Jersey makes me ready to get to work on Day One. 

“Let’s be clear about the two visions in this race: I am ready to stand up to an extreme Washington that doesn’t have New Jersey’s best interests at heart. Jack has already surrendered to them. It’s our duty to meet the moment and live up to our state’s motto of liberty and prosperity, because a Trump yes man like Jack Ciattarelli in Trenton will threaten it all. 

“While Jack is for Trump, I am for New Jersey. A New Jersey where housing is affordable so our kids can afford to live here, middle-class families can buy a home, and our seniors can afford to stay. A New Jersey where we finally take control of our energy future, and slash the cost of utilities. A New Jersey where a woman’s right to an abortion is non-negotiable, and we respect the rule of law, due process, and the Constitution. 

“That’s what my life has been about — service to others — since I took my first oath to the Constitution at the U.S. Naval Academy. We had a saying: Ship. Shipmate. Self. Because those were the order of our priorities — our missions were never about a single person, they were missions for our country. That’s how we built this campaign, together for New Jersey, and that’s how we’re going to protect our state from the chaos of Trump’s Washington. 

“This is our time. This is our future. This is our New Jersey that we will save together.”

With five other candidates — including three mayors, a U.S. congressman, and a former senate president — and no organizational line, this was the most competitive gubernatorial primary in history. It included well-resourced candidates who had never lost a campaign. But Mikie consistently stood above the pack, despite being outspent and being the final candidate to enter the race. In fact, her opponents dropped $40 million in paid communications before Mikie went on the air. Combined, Mikie was outspent by more than six-to-one, including campaigns and outside entities supporting other candidates. 

Mikie’s campaign was powered by grassroots support. Throughout the race, nearly 2,000 volunteers knocked on 120,000 doors, made 200,000 calls, and over half a million text messages to voters. She earned support from organizations like the Sierra Club, League of Conservation Voters, Chatham Moms for Change, Door to Door Democracy, New Jersey Firefighters Mutual Benevolent Association, Laborers International Union of North America, and more.  

Throughout the campaign, Mikie offered a comprehensive and detailed vision for driving down costs with her Affordability Agenda and was the only candidate in the field who shared a plan for protecting our kids and our democracy with her Online Safety Agenda. That Agenda would make New Jersey a national leader in safe and accountable tech, and former Rep. Tom Malinowski called it “the most comprehensive I have seen from any candidate in the country.” 
 

###

data.title: New Jerseyans Unify Around Mikie Sherrill After a Decisive Win
data.description:
Mikie’s a fighter who serves New Jersey with tenacity, is willing to take on tough fights, and has a proven record of forming broad coalitions”


BLOOMFIELD — Mikie is carrying the momentum from her commanding victory to bring together Democrats and Republicans in support of her leadership and her vision for the future of the Garden State. 

Since winning the nomination, Mikie has earned the endorsements of Governor Phil Murphy, Senators Cory Booker and Andy Kim, and Former Governor Christine Todd Whitman. Mikie has gained the support of groups across New Jersey, including the New Jersey College Democrats, New Jersey 11th for Change, SOMA Action, and AFSCME New Jersey Council 63. Here is what they have to say about why they are supporting Mikie:

“Mikie earned the trust and support of voters because they know she is a fighter — from her time serving as a U.S. Navy pilot to her role flipping a longtime Republican congressional district. It’s now time for Democrats to unite behind her and defeat President Trump’s hand-picked Republican nominee, Jack Ciattarelli,” said Governor Phil Murphy.

“In Congress, we have seen a fighter who serves New Jersey with tenacity, is willing to take on the tough fights, and has a proven record of forming broad coalitions with people across the political spectrum. We are proud to endorse Mikie Sherrill for Governor and will work united to win in November,” said Senators Cory Booker and Andy Kim.

“She’s the right person for the job,” former Republican Governor Christine Todd Whitman said of Sherrill in an interview with The Inquirer. “I’ve met with her. She knows how to organize. She knows how to manage and to lead [...] Frankly, Jack has changed from the person I knew decades ago.”

“Half-hearted unity only strengthens the hand of an opposition that has made it clear they refuse to govern in the interests of working people, marginalized communities, or future generations,” said the New Jersey College Democrats. “Congresswoman Sherrill has been fighting for us for decades. From the Navy to her time as a federal prosecutor to the halls of congress, she has always had our back.”

“Mikie Sherrill has a deep respect for public service and a strong track record of standing with working people,” said AFSCME New Jersey Council 63 Executive Director Steve Tully. “She understands the critical role that AFSCME members play in keeping our communities running, from public health and public safety to essential municipal and state services, and she knows that work is under attack. Mikie Sherrill has proven time and again that she stands with public workers, and we are confident that as Governor, she will be a powerful champion for labor and a fierce defender of our rights.” 

“The results of this election will resonate nationally. New Jerseyans need to show the country that we unequivocally reject the agenda of the Trump Republican Party, and there is no better way of doing so than by electing Mikie Sherrill as our next governor,” said Erika Malinoski, co-president of SOMA Action.

“In our years as constituents in Representative Sherrill’s congressional district, we have come to respect her integrity, her commitment to public service, and her authentic dedication to our Constitution and the rule of law. We admire her thoughtful and strategic approach to complex problems, and her willingness to speak out bravely when she believes the time is right. During this time of political turbulence, we trust her to be a powerful guardian of democracy and protector of our rights — a bulwark against the abuses likely to descend upon us from the Trump administration — while working to implement a positive and pragmatic new vision for New Jersey. She has the wisdom and toughness necessary to meet this moment,” said NJ 11th for Change.

In the News:

WATCH: Steve Kornacki: How Mikie Sherrill and Jack Ciattarelli won their NJ governor primaries - MSNBC

Opinion | Mikie Sherrill’s New Jersey win points the way for Democrats - The Washington Post

  • As Democrats seek a way out of the wilderness, they should be paying attention to what just happened — and is about to happen — in a blue state that swung sharply to the right in last year’s presidential race. 

  • As a gubernatorial candidate, Sherrill has focused heavily on making life in New Jersey more affordable. But she rejects the advice from some that Democrats should be running exclusively on kitchen table issues.

  • “I’m like, well, if I’m not talking about rights and freedoms, why am I running here? I’ve taken multiple oaths to the Constitution. I’m not backing away from that,” [Sherrill] said. “I’m not somehow going to cave to Trump, because he’s trying to shred the Constitution and ignore the courts and the governors and the states and attack the very people he’s supposed to serve. I’m not going to just say nothing.”
     

How Mikie Sherrill won the New Jersey Democratic primary for governor - The Philadelphia Inquirer

  • In a crowded race for governor, U.S. Rep. Mikie Sherrill built a statewide coalition in the Democratic primary that stretched from New Jersey’s northernmost county down to Cape May.

  • Though she was the last to join the six-person race, Sherrill was long considered the front-runner. But experts did not rule out a path to victory for anyone in the race, so the decisiveness of her win — declared just 40 minutes after polls closed — came as a surprise to some political observers who had anticipated a more competitive race.

  • She captured 15 of the state’s 21 counties. None of her opponents was able to build the same level of statewide appeal of the federal lawmaker and former Navy helicopter pilot.

  • Sherrill’s campaign recruited nearly 2,000 volunteers, made about 580,000 phone calls and 555,700 texts, and knocked on more than 120,000 doors, according to her campaign’s memo.


Mikie Sherrill is dedicated to public service and has been a lifelong champion for equality and opportunity. She will build broad coalitions to advance a vision that will help New Jerseyans lower costs while making sure families in communities across New Jersey get a fair shot. Mikie will lead a unified front in the fight against attacks from Donald Trump and his lackey, Jack Ciattarelli.

###

data.title: Early Childhood
data.description:
Access to quality child care is a lifeline for families and strengthens our economy, but far too many parents either can't find care, or even when it is available, can't afford it. Some parents have to make the impossible choice of enrolling their child in a program that doesn’t fit their budget or leaving their job to care for them. This issue is personal to me as a mother of four — I remember when I was looking for child care and had to make that decision. I will work to bring down the cost of child care for families and allow parents the ability to rejoin the workforce or take on more hours at work, strengthening their family’s financial security. 


In Congress, I’ve tackled this issue head-on. I introduced legislation — modeled after the military and Head Start — that would cap a family's out-of-pocket costs for child care at 7 percent of their income and bolster the early childhood education workforce to ensure that every family can find and afford high-quality child care. I helped pass legislation that expanded the federal child tax credit, which lifted nearly three million children out of poverty. As governor, I will expand New Jersey’s child tax credit, which would reduce child poverty and help families afford child care — or anything else their family needs. 

Our local businesses feel the significant strain when their employees can't find reliable child care. I will work with New Jersey employers to establish support programs that enable them to offer the child care options their employees need. Affordable child care isn't just necessary for parents — it’s essential for employers and New Jersey’s economy. 

Read more about Mikie’s Affordability Agenda, and how it will make raising kids more affordable.

data.title: ICYMI: Mikie Sherrill Touts Strong Support for Labor, Slams Ciattarelli's Anti-Worker Record
data.description:
Mikie: “New Jersey is sure as hell not a right to work state, and I refuse to surrender our future to someone who will make us one.”
 

ATLANTIC CITY — This morning, Mikie Sherrill addressed the New Jersey State Building and Construction Trades Council conference in Atlantic City. She outlined how her administration will use union labor to build more housing and drive down costs for families, fix New Jersey’s aging infrastructure, and meet our state’s energy needs. Mikie contrasted her record of standing up for labor and investing in working families — including a 100% lifetime score from the AFL-CIO — with Jack Ciattarelli’s long history of weakening protections for organized labor and opposing investments that would create jobs for workers across the state.

Below are excerpts from her remarks as prepared for delivery:

My promise to all of you, is that as a former federal prosecutor I understand strong laws are meaningless without enforcement. In my administration I will bolster our enforcement efforts to protect workers and ask my Attorney General to stop settling every case, and prosecute bad actors to send a clear signal in the industry that cheating on public works will no longer be tolerated as the cost of doing business. 

Unions built New Jersey, and you all have a critical role to play as we work to make the Garden State into the world’s premier manufacturing and innovation hub and bring costs down for families. That will involve building all across our state using labor from the Building Trades — from homes and new energy infrastructure, to roads, bridges, and new business facilities. I’m up for the challenge, and I know your members are too.

[...]

As New Jerseyans’ utility bills go up, we’re also going to need to make bold investments in our energy supply. As governor, I’ll host solar on state properties, and I’ll work with the Building Trades to get it done. We’ll lead the nation in clean, cheap power while making our state energy independent.

Just last week, I visited a solar farm in Southampton Township where over 200 union workers across multiple crafts turned a capped landfill into a source of energy that is lowering utility bills for local residents.

Like so many solar projects across the state, the farm used Inflation Reduction Act tax credits to reduce construction costs and hire union workers.

While we need solar in the short term, if we want to meet our economy’s long-term energy needs, we must build our nuclear energy infrastructure. I will expand our nuclear energy generating capacity to take on our energy crisis. That’s another opportunity to create union jobs into New Jersey to move our state into the future.

I’ll invest in the people who keep our economy running. I’ll expand helmets to hard hats programs and invest in high-quality registered apprenticeship programs. And as governor, I’ll be the best governor for business and for labor.

I have big goals for the Garden State, and we are going to have to work together to get this done. 

[...]

I want to tell you a little bit about what we are up against in my opponent Jack Ciattarelli.

A civil rights champion once said, “When someone shows you who they are, believe them the first time."

My opponent has repeatedly shown all of us exactly who is – he courted and received the endorsement of the ABC, not once but twice. In fact, I’m sure you saw because I know you track this, the day after he won the primary this year, the ABC advertised their full throated support for him.

His support from ABC is no coincidence. Time and time again he has turned his back on labor. When he was a legislator and had the chance to expand PLA’s to more projects in New Jersey, Jack’s vote was crystal clear. Jack said NO. 

He had another chance to stand up for workers when he cast his vote on a common-sense, bipartisan legislation that required certain bidders to provide proof they would pay the prevailing wage. What did he do? Jack said NO. 

Many of you remember the summer of 2016 when the TTF ran out of money forcing projects all across the state to be halted, leaving thousands of building trades members jobless. When a bipartisan compromise was reached that would fund the TTF and get your members back to work, do you know what Jack did? Jack said NO.

And then, there is the Republican Price Hike Bill, which rolls back the tax credits that are funding clean energy projects across the State. The elimination of these credits means that countless union workers could lose their jobs. 

But perhaps even worse, it cuts off the development of new projects and ends the opportunity to create thousands of new union jobs. Did Jack stand and fight for these projects or these jobs? Jack said NO.

And, throughout his career, Jack has worked to dismantle state pensions and health benefits, voted against raising the minimum wage five times, and is now endorsed by three state senate and assembly members who have introduced right to work legislation.  Again and again, Jack said NO.

Republican Governors all across the country have shown us who they are, by pushing right to work laws, dismantling prevailing wage protections and finding innovative ways to limit the rights of unions and your members.

New Jersey is sure as hell not a right to work state, and I refuse to surrender our future to someone who will make us one.

Look, Jack has told us who he is. All I am asking you to do is believe him.

While some will paint this election as a Democrat vs. Republican narrative, that’s not what this election is about.

I have a vision for workers in NJ.  I will champion PLAs, I will demand my AG to go after cheaters, I will be bold in encouraging innovation and meeting our energy needs. I’ll be the best governor for business AND for labor. All of this against a guy who has shown us he is unwilling to stand up for workers at every turn and is willing to follow a playbook that looks to dismantle all the values we all hold so dearly.

The future of the labor movement in New Jersey is on the ballot in November.  As a candidate and as Governor, labor will always have a seat at my table.   
 

###

data.title: ICYMI: Mikie Sherrill Launches New Website Calling On Jack To Release His Taxes — Just Like She Did 4 Months Ago
data.description:
For the past three thousand plus days, Jack has refused to release his taxes: what is he hiding?

BLOOMFIELD — Mikie Sherill has gone above and beyond in her financial disclosures, releasing “exact values of her finances,” two years of both state and federal tax returns, and providing a “greater level of transparency and detail than what [she] is required by law to make public” — now it’s Jack’s turn. Over the past decade, Jack has refused to release his taxes, leaving New Jerseyans in the dark about his conflicts of interest, how he made his money, and who’s been paying him as he spent the last eight years unemployed and running for governor. 

New Jerseyans deserve transparency from gubernatorial candidates. But here’s what we do know about Jack: He made $3 million from the pharmaceutical companies that fueled the opioid addiction crisis — what else is he hiding? 

“We already know Jack made $3 million peddling misinformation, exacerbating the opioid crisis that tore apart families and cost hundreds of thousands of New Jerseyans their lives. How else did Jack make money? Jack’s a professional campaigner and he’s spent the last six years running for governor. He needs to release his tax returns like Mikie did back in May. Mikie went further and released the ‘exact values of her finances’ to be transparent and accountable to the people of New Jersey — it’s time for Jack to do the same,” said Mikie Sherrill for Governor Communications Director Sean Higgins.

data.title: SEIU NJ State Council Endorses Mikie Sherrill for Governor
data.description:
NEWARK — The SEIU New Jersey State Council—representing thousands of nursing home workers, municipal service workers, motor vehicle inspection workers, resident physicians, and employees in the laundry, food service, and distribution industries—officially endorses Mikie Sherrill in the 2025 race for Governor of New Jersey.

“New Jersey’s working families deserve a Governor who will champion justice, opportunity, and the dignity of every person,” said Megan Chambers, President of the SEIU NJ State Council and Co-Manager of the LDFS Joint Board, Workers United SEIU. “In Mikie Sherrill, we see a leader with a clear vision for protecting our civil liberties, defending our democracy, and ensuring immigrant communities are treated with humanity and respect. 

“New Jersey needs a Governor who’s going to stand up for everyday people—someone who listens, who leads with common sense, and who doesn’t back down from doing what’s right.

“The SEIU NJ State Council believes Mikie Sherrill is the leader New Jersey can count on to fight for democracy, preserve civility, and strengthen the voice of working people. We are proud to support her in this important gubernatorial campaign,” concluded Ms. Chambers.

The SEIU NJ State Council is composed of unions representing service employees across the state, including health care, warehouse, laundry, and school cafeteria workers. Our diverse membership also includes motor vehicle inspectors, resident physicians, and municipal employees in Newark. The council includes 1199 SEIU Healthcare Workers East, Laundry, Distribution and Food Service Joint Board of Workers United, The Committee of Interns and Residents, and 32BJ Motor Vehicle Inspectors.

data.title: ICYMI: CNN Highlights Mikie’s “Relentless Focus” on Affordability
data.description:
With her plan to stop the utility rate hikes and Save You Time and Money Agenda, Mikie has a “relentless focus” on affordability

Jack Ciattarelli campaigns to gain favor with Trump and MAGA

BLOOMFIELD — Mikie Sherrill is running for governor with a “relentless focus” on affordability, as she works to make life easier for New Jersey families by driving down costs.

CNN notes how the “soaring utility prices have emerged as a major campaign issue in New Jersey, where residential electricity costs have spiked much more than the national average,” and covered Mikie’s plan to declare a State of Emergency on Utility Costs and end the rate hikes. 

While Mikie is laser focused on lowering costs for Garden State families, Jack is focused on cozying up to Trump and MAGA extremists.

Take a look:

CNN: With the economy faltering, Democrats in fall races focus on affordability

  • The Democratic candidates in this fall’s top statewide races have chosen a relentless focus on one word: affordability.

  • Rep. Mikie Sherrill rolled out a “Save You Time and Money” plan in New Jersey.

  • There’s evidence that the economy and rising costs are a key vulnerability for President Donald Trump with independent voters…

  • Soaring utility prices have emerged as a major campaign issue in New Jersey where residential electricity costs have spiked much more than the national average.

  • Half of New Jerseyans said they have some level of difficulty affording utility bills, according to a Rutgers/Eagleton poll released in July. More than half said they had some level of difficulty affording health care costs, groceries, and housing payments.

  • In August, Sherrill unveiled a plan to freeze utility rates, a proposal she highlighted in her first ad of the general election campaign.

  • “On day one as governor, I’m declaring a state of emergency on utility costs, using emergency powers to end these rate hikes and drive down your bills,” Sherrill said in the ad.

data.title: Mikie Sherrill Announces Sen. Vin Gopal as Campaign Chair
data.description:
Vice Chairs Include Patricia Campos Medina, Justin Dews, Karin Elkis


BLOOMFIELD — Mikie Sherrill today announced Senator Vin Gopal (D-Monmouth) as Campaign Chair. Senator Gopal is part of a new generation of leaders in Trenton who, like Mikie, has won in Republican territory by building a broad coalition that includes all New Jerseyans, not just the Democratic Party. 

“Mikie is a proven bipartisan leader who has a history of community service and bringing people together. Whether it is her service in the military, as a prosecutor, or as a Member of Congress, she has always put service first. We contrast that with career politician Jack Ciattarelli, who has been running for office for 40 years, unsuccessfully for Governor multiple times, and has taken every policy position possible. He has already made it clear that the only person he plans to answer to is Donald Trump, not the people of New Jersey. This election couldn't have a clearer contrast,” said Vin Gopal. 

“Our campaign is full speed ahead to win in November, and we’re assembling the team to do just that. So I couldn’t be more excited to announce Senator Vin Gopal as our Campaign Chair. Vin has been a tireless supporter of our campaign in Monmouth and an important partner as I take on the bad actors that are driving up prescription drug prices. And just as I do, Vin knows what it takes to win tough races and will be an essential part of our operation to beat Jack and protect the state we all love. I’m also grateful for our Vice Chairs — Patricia, Justin, and Karin — whose talent and expertise will help build the broad coalition we need to beat Jack in November,” said Mikie Sherrill. 

As Campaign Chair, Senator Gopal will head up Mikie’s fundraising efforts and be a key surrogate on the campaign trail. This announcement comes after Mikie’s commanding win in the Democratic primary, where she defied conventional wisdom of the race and outpaced her nearest competitor by more than 100,000 votes. 

Mikie is also announcing Dr. Patricia Campos-Medina, Justin Dews, and Karin Elkis as her Campaign Vice Chairs.

Dr. Patricia Campos-Media is a former U.S. Senate candidate and prominent community organizer with deep experience in labor and Latino voter mobilization. During the primary election, she worked extensively to engage the Latino community across New Jersey for Mikie.

Justin Dews, an attorney, former White House Associate Counsel, and former Senior Counsel to Governor Murphy who currently serves as Chair of the New Jersey Clemency Advisory Board, is an expert on criminal justice and public policy.

Karin Elkis is the Co-Chair of the New Jersey-Israel Commission, with strong ties and a command of issues facing state government, South Jersey, and the Jewish community.

data.title: ICYMI: New Jerseyans are Concerned that Jack Can’t Stop Talking About a 10% Sales Tax
data.description:
New Jersey Independent: “Residents facing increasing grocery and energy bills are criticizing Republican gubernatorial candidate Jack Ciattarelli for saying he’s open to a 10% sales tax.”

BLOOMFIELD —  Jack Ciattarelli keeps talking about a “10% sales tax on everything, including on food and clothing,” and Garden State families are concerned. 

The New Jersey Independent reports that New Jerseyans are “worried about Jack Ciattarelli, the Republican candidate for governor in New Jersey, saying he’s open to changing the tax structure in the Garden State, which could include… increasing the sales tax.”

The New Jersey Globe notes that Jack’s own record speaks for itself with his “long trail [of statements]… considering a 10% sales tax modeled after Tennessee.”

“Jack voted to raise taxes in every elected office he’s held, and now he keeps talking about a 10% sales tax on everything. I want to make one thing very clear: there will be no 10% sales tax on groceries or clothing in New Jersey when I'm governor,” said Mikie Sherrill.

New Jersey Independent: New Jersey families say an increased sales tax would make life worse

  • Residents facing increasing grocery and energy bills are criticizing Republican gubernatorial candidate Jack Ciattarelli for saying he’s open to a 10% sales tax.

  • These days, as grocery and energy costs climb, Flemington residents Sherrill DeGenova and her husband, Michael, are being especially careful with their money. 

  • They’re not in an emergency financial situation, but there are signs that the economy is moving in a worrisome direction for them, explained DeGenova, a retired speech therapist who, along with her husband, relies on Social Security and Medicare. They are also caregivers for their 30-year-old son, who has autism. Their daughter, who previously had breast cancer and had to declare bankruptcy due to medical costs, lives with them as well.

  • “The funding that we have is very limited, and I’m already feeling it just from the end of the summer because power went up. Our oil went up. We don’t have gas, but our electrical went up,” DeGenova said.

  • Food bills, too, have soared for her family. For every $100 they had been spending at the grocery store, they’re now paying about $150, DeGenova said. 

  • It’s not just that food and electricity costs are increasing. The DeGenovas are deeply concerned about changes to their son’s Medicaid benefits after congressional Republicans and President Donald Trump slashed funding for the national health insurance program that provides coverage for lower-income individuals, people with disabilities, and eligible pregnant people, among others. The GOP lawmakers and president carved about $1 trillion from Medicaid over the next 10 years as part of their One Big Beautiful Bill Act, which state officials said could result in 300,000 New Jersey residents losing health care coverage.

  • “Our son, who’s autistic and intellectually disabled, he uses Medicaid for everything,” DeGenova said. “Otherwise, it’s out of pocket for us. So, a day program, a job coach to keep him on track and keep him safe for the 10 hours a week that he works.”

  • If costs continue to rise, or there are changes to their health care benefits, their financial situation could become much more precarious, DeGenova said. That’s why she is worried about Jack Ciattarelli, the Republican candidate for governor in New Jersey, saying he’s open to changing the tax structure in the Garden State, which could include eliminating the state income tax and increasing the sales tax to 10%, according to audio captured during a campaign rally in Bergen County. Ciattarelli is running against U.S. Rep. Mikie Sherrill, the Democratic nominee for governor, in the Nov. 4 election.

  • Currently, New Jersey assesses a 6.625% sales tax on “most tangible personal property, specified digital products and certain services unless specifically exempt under New Jersey law,” the state Division of Taxation’s website notes. Most grocery store food items and clothing are exempt from the sales tax.

  • Wintischa Wilson, a community activist from Rahway, said an increased sales tax would further stress New Jerseyans who are already dealing with rising costs. A Rutgers survey released in July found that half or more of New Jerseyans are struggling to afford necessities like groceries, rent, health care, utilities, and mortgage.

  • “Now everything is up: the food, the taxes,” Wilson said. “It’s crazy for people that just have a normal nine-to-five, making about $40,000, $53,000 a year.” 

  • “If you make the tax even higher, what are we supposed to do?” she continued. “The food pantry lines are definitely getting longer.”

  • Lower-income residents are typically hit the hardest financially when a state eliminates its income tax and instead relies on revenue from an increased sales tax, according to a 2023 paper published by the National Conference for State Legislatures. Those with lower incomes typically spend about three-quarters of their earnings on items that are subject to sales tax, while higher-income earners spend about a sixth of their income on taxed items, the report said.

  • Dan Cassino, a professor of government and politics at Fairleigh Dickinson University, noted that a consumption tax-based system, which includes sales tax, is more vulnerable to changes in the economy than an income tax-based system.

  • New Jerseyans are struggling in this economy, with people working two or three jobs to make ends meet, Wilson said… a new sales tax on food and clothing, would only exacerbate those issues, she said. 

###

data.title: Hotel and Gaming Trades Council Endorses Mikie Sherrill for Governor
data.description:
BLOOMFIELD — Today, the Hotel and Gaming Trades Council endorsed Mikie Sherrill for governor because of her strong record standing up for working families, collective bargaining rights, and commitment to expanding opportunity to all New Jerseyans.

“I am honored to have the support of the Hotel and Gaming Trades Council as we fight to build a more affordable Garden State. Unions built New Jersey, but with Donald Trump, their rights are under constant threat. We know that an attack on workers anywhere is an attack on workers everywhere. That’s why it’s critically important to defeat Jack Ciattarelli and his union-busting, anti-worker agenda at the ballot box this November. I won’t hesitate to stand up for New Jerseyans, and together we will ensure that the members of the HTC have the opportunity to thrive here in the Garden State,” said Mikie Sherrill. 

“We are proud to endorse Mikie Sherrill for governor. Mikie understands what’s important to working people in New Jersey, and as governor I know she’s going to fight for our priorities. She has our back, and will stand shoulder-to-shoulder with us as we fight for better pay, better benefits, and dignity in the workplace. HTC members will be doing all they can to see Mikie win this election,” said HTC President Rich Maroko. 

Mikie is the only candidate in this race who will stand up for the workers who built this great state. That’s why she’s earned a 100% lifetime AFL-CIO score. 

From her first day in Congress, Mikie has fought to expand collective bargaining rights, increase wages, and ensure that labor always has a seat at the table. Meanwhile, Jack Ciattarelli has taken every possible opportunity to make life more expensive for working families, reject Project Labor Agreements, and attack workers’ pensions and health benefits for workers.

data.title: Republican Energy Attack Ad Blowing Hot Air — "The Commercial Misleads Voters”
data.description:
MAGA Republicans Caught Lying — Again

Ad “misleads voters” and “manipulates [Mikie’s] words ‘into appearing to have said the precise opposite of what she actually said.’”

BLOOMFIELD — Jack Ciattarelli and his MAGA allies “exploit” Mikie’s remarks as they “push out a deceptively edited clip” of her that “leaves out the point of her observation.”

The Philadelphia Inquirer notes that “Sherrill was actually criticizing unsuccessful Democratic messaging that over time has made people think clean energy would result in higher electric bills while making the case that the state should invest in ‘clean, cheap power.’”

“MAGA Republicans would push out a deliberately misleading and blatantly false ad to cover up the fact that desperate, lying Jack Ciattarelli’s 100% MAGA agenda would only drive up costs,” said Mikie Sherrill for Governor spokesperson Sean Higgins.

Take a look for yourself: 

Philadelphia Inquirer: Mikie Sherrill accused Jack Ciattarelli of deceptively editing her remarks… 

  • In a seven-figure ad buy, a PAC funded by the Republican Governors Association is pushing out a deceptively edited clip…

  • But Sherrill’s campaign said the ad manipulates her words “into appearing to have said the precise opposite of what she actually said.”

  • Without those edits, Sherrill was actually criticizing unsuccessful Democratic messaging that over time has made people think clean energy would result in higher electric bills while making the case that the state should invest in “clean, cheap power.”

  • The clip is from a late March interview Sherrill gave on the Dean Obeidallah Show, in which she said:

  • “We have to do better … sometimes our messaging in the Democratic Party — not great,” she said. “Meaning, I think for years, we’ve sort of said we need to move into clean power, and there’s almost been this understanding, it’s going to cost you an arm and a leg, but if you’re a good person, you’ll do it.”

  • She goes on to argue that New Jersey has been “sleeping on solar,” and not investing enough in clean energy that could lower utility costs in the way other states, like Texas, are.

  • “Now that we’re actually in that place that we promised, it was going to be cheaper than any other source of power, people are skeptical,” she said. “So I have to tell people in New Jersey like, look, Texas is leading in solar, and everybody in New Jersey sort of feels like, if Texas is doing it, they’re not doing it because it’s just clean. It’s got to be economical, right?”

  • Sean Higgins, a spokesperson for Sherrill’s campaign, said the RGA ad is “a false, incoherent life preserver thrown to a desperate, lying candidate who’s covering up his 100% MAGA agenda that would only drive up costs.” Sherrill’s campaign frequently attacks Ciattarelli for his support of President Donald Trump, particularly regarding economic impacts from the One Big Beautiful Bill Act.

  • “This is a blatantly misleading, desperate smear from Jack Ciattarelli’s MAGA allies and makes crystal clear they’re terrified that Mikie’s plan for a State of Emergency on Utility Costs is dominating the in-state conversation,” Higgins also said, referring to her promise to freeze utility rates for a year.

Semafor: “The Republican Governors Association created a PAC to run anti-Sherrill ads, which exploit some… moments the Democrat had during the crowded primary. One PAC ad uses a clip of Sherrill talking about renewable energy that’s “gonna cost you an arm and a leg,” but leaves out the point of her observation: that cleaner power is now affordable.”

NJ.com: “National Republicans released a TV ad Friday with a video clip of Sherrill… the commercial misleads voters by editing a small portion of an old interview out of context — and Sherrill was actually saying the opposite.”

data.title: ICYMI: “Mikie Sherrill Is Right. NJ Must Declare An Emergency on Utility Costs”
data.description:
As prices rise, “we need” Mikie’s bold plan, writes former AARP advocate

BLOOMFIELD — New Jerseyans up and down the state are coming out in support of Mikie’s plan to declare a State of Emergency on Utility Costs to stop the rate hikes. Residents are being crushed by sky-high utility costs and Mikie’s plan will provide immediate relief. Read why Evelyn Liebman, former Director of Advocacy for AARP New Jersey, says Mikie’s plan “just makes sense” and New Jerseyans “need it.” 

Take a look: 

NorthJersey.com: Mikie Sherrill is right. NJ must declare an emergency on utility costs | Opinion By Evelyn Liebman 
 

  • The first rule of holes: When you’re stuck in one, stop digging. This is precisely what Rep. Mikie Sherrill’s call to declare a state of emergency on New Jersey utility costs is all about. And we need it. 
     

  • Under the New Jersey state constitution, the governor has the legal authority to declare a state of emergency during natural or man-made disasters, such as severe weather events, civil unrest or public health crises. The primary goal of the declaration is to mobilize government resources to respond to the crisis. Again, that's precisely what our next governor should do. An all-of-government response is needed.
     

  • New Jersey’s utility companies are requesting hundreds of millions of dollars in new rate hikes — on top of the average 20% electric bill increases we were hit with this summer. Sherrill’s pledge to stop electricity rate hikes and focus on ways to get ourselves out of this mess is a necessary first step.
     

  • There is no question we are in a bad situation and it’s about time New Jersey stops making it worse. Sherrill’s proposal to stop digging this hole by freezing utility costs just makes sense. It’s about being able to stay in the homes and communities we’ve built our lives around, and about living without the constant worry of how to pay the next electric bill.
     

  • I spent my career fighting for consumers in our state. That’s why I support Sherrill’s promise to tackle this crisis head on, put consumers first, and stop electric rate hikes.
     

  • Evelyn Liebman has advocated on behalf of New Jersey’s utility ratepayers for decades. She is the former director of advocacy for AARP New Jersey, was the director of organizing and advocacy for New Jersey Citizen Action and a former rate analyst at the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities.

data.title: Patricia Campos-Medina Endorses Mikie Sherrill for Governor
data.description:
Campos-Medina — a Prominent Progressive Leader — Will Serve as a Senior Advisor and Official Surrogate for the Campaign 

BLOOMFIELD — Today, Dr. Patricia Campos-Medina — a prominent labor leader and community organizer — announced she is supporting Mikie Sherrill in the race for New Jersey Governor. Dr. Campos Medina will also serve as a senior advisor and official surrogate for Mikie’s campaign.

“Now is the time for a different type of leadership in New Jersey and that’s why I’m endorsing Mikie Sherrill’s campaign for governor,” said Dr. Patricia Campos-Medina. “Mikie understands to her core what public service is about. We need a leader in Trenton who’s in this not for themselves, but for working families struggling in a changing economy: To increase wages and benefits for workers, to protect our rights and freedoms, and to provide opportunities for communities whose voices are often ignored. We need a fearless Democratic governor to stand up to Trump’s threats on New Jersey — and I am excited to hit the campaign trail for Mikie and help build a winning coalition for the Democratic Primary.”

“I’m absolutely thrilled to have Patricia’s support in this race. Throughout the course of her career, she has demonstrated bold leadership — from the labor movement advocating for better wages to expanding democracy here in New Jersey,” said Mikie Sherrill. “From the moment I launched this campaign, I’ve said it’s one we’re going to build together and I’m grateful to have Patricia’s counsel and voice on the campaign trail.”

Campos-Medina ran for U.S. Senate, coming in second place in the June 2024 Democratic primary. She has been an outspoken advocate to expand democracy and ballot access in New Jersey. She has a long trajectory of supporting women to run for office and leads efforts to train Latina women to expand their ranks in NJ government and politics. Campos-Medina is a labor educator and political scientist — leading research, policy innovation, and training to advance worker justice, collective bargaining rights, and the interest of American workers. She is a Visiting Fellow at the Eagleton Institute of Politics, Rutgers University-New Brunswick, and a board member of several progressive organizations including the Network Action Fund, supporting innovation in union organizing for workers in the gig, care, and low-wage economy. Prior to joining academia, she held top leadership roles in national and local labor unions such as SEIU, UNITE HERE, Workers United (formerly UNITE), and LCLAA AFL-CIO. She is a proud daughter, wife and mother who understands the challenges facing working families in New Jersey.

data.title: ICYMI: Mikie Sherrill's Open Letter to DNC Chair Candidates
data.description:
“New Jersey shares something else with the rest of America: We face challenges ranging from how much things cost today to how much faith we have that tomorrow will be better.” 

“The national and state Republicans already have their sights set on flipping New Jersey in 2025 and previous levels of Democratic spending in New Jersey will not be sufficient.”

BLOOMFIELD — Yesterday, Mikie Sherrill sent an open letter to candidates for Democratic National Committee chair, calling for a $10 million investment in New Jersey to set Democrats up for success up and down the ballot in 2025.

Read the full letter below: 

I flew helicopters in the Navy, where I had the advantage of seeing things from the air – the big picture.

And after being a mom who commutes to having the honor of representing New Jersey in public office, I also know a lot about roads. And I can guarantee that the road to a successful future for the Democratic Party runs straight through New Jersey — starting now, with the 2025 election.

New Jersey is one of only two states with a gubernatorial campaign this year and it should be a place where the national Democratic Party fully engages. But Democrats need to focus on New Jersey for reasons far beyond the immediate election calendar.  

To get the future right, Democrats can start by getting New Jersey right. We are urban, suburban, and rural. We are the most diverse state in the nation. We are blue-collar and white-collar. We have strong Democratic constituencies, a whole lot of unaffiliated voters, and, yes, Republican communities. In other words, we are America.

New Jersey shares something else with the rest of America: We face challenges ranging from how much things cost today to how much faith we have that tomorrow will be better. We are absolutely tuned into the fact our rights and freedoms are under relentless attack. People are rightfully anxious, and some are asking whether the Democratic Party still understands them. Too many voters think Democrats are out of touch and we paid the price in November. 

Here in New Jersey, we are proud of our success electing Democrats who care deeply about delivering for families — from local races to battleground congressional districts to the United States Senate. Yet that record should not give false comfort to anyone. In the last 32 years, Republicans have won the governorship just as often as Democrats: 16 years of Democratic governors and 16 years of Republican governors. And in 2024, the state of New Jersey shifted 10 points in Trump’s direction — as clear of a warning as the Democratic Party could get. 

All of this is why I am charging into 2025 determined to win and with zero complacency about the terrain. Let me be really clear: The DNC must show up in New Jersey because the next generation of the party cannot take anyone, anywhere — even in "blue" areas — for granted. The kind of politics that brought us to this moment will not deliver us the future we aspire to in New Jersey and across our country.

Democrats must stand up to Donald Trump in the countless ways he is a threat to American values and American progress. And we can’t stop there. To win the future, Americans need to see Democrats as more than the anti-Trump party. Democrats need to be the party that makes things work for families and makes things better for the American people.

That’s why, as the next DNC Chair, you need to commit at least $10 million dollars to New Jersey starting Day 1. In previous cycles, the DNC has donated approximately $200,000 annually. That’s not going to cut it — the national and state Republicans already have their sights set on flipping New Jersey in 2025 and previous levels of Democratic spending in New Jersey will not be sufficient. 

The new DNC Chair must work hand in hand with New Jersey to build up and expand the Democratic base in the Garden State and bring new voters into the fold. Our party and candidates MUST be both willing and prepared to move confidently into spaces where voters may disagree. We need to invest in new and nontraditional media, reaching lower information voters across platforms that meet people where they are and disseminating our message not only during election season, but year-round. We also must invest in voter registration as Democrats continue to lose ground to Republicans when it comes to registering voters — and then we need to immediately and consistently communicate that our party will be fighting for what families need. Bottom line: we need to build a meaningful and long-term relationship with voters rather than a fleeting and transactional one come election time. 

My record of running with a winning message is clear. I delivered the largest red-to-blue swing in the nation in 2018 and I have consistently outperformed the top of the ticket. I’ve also worked hard to build our party down ballot from crafting messaging guides on Supreme Court decisions affecting access to abortion and reproductive care to raising money for local candidates. As a result, when New Jersey shifted to the right in 2024, I helped down-ballot Democrats not only defend their seats but expand their footprint in my district — of the 39 candidates who ran, all but one won their seats. I am ready and willing to partner with you to take this success into 2025 when we face down the Republican onslaught and elect New Jersey’s next Democratic governor.   

The Navy taught me that you have three choices when things are tough — lead, follow, or get out of the way. I have always chosen to lead. I know leadership means bringing real solutions to the table — and that begins with actually listening to what voters have to say. That’s something our party needs to do better and needs to do right now.

New Jersey is a state built on innovation, dating back to our founding — the perfect laboratory for testing the ideas, tactics, and technologies that will shape the next Democratic Party. But make no mistake, this isn’t just an academic exercise now with Donald Trump in Washington. State leadership matters more than ever. And our party may not know it yet, but it’s counting on us to get this right. 

New Jersey is ready to lead, and I’m asking the DNC to join us.

###

data.title: Statement by Mikie Sherrill on the Anniversary of Roe v. Wade
data.description:
BLOOMFIELD — Today, Mikie Sherrill released the following statement on the 52nd anniversary of the Roe v. Wade decision: 

“Here in New Jersey, we respect women’s abortion rights and access to comprehensive reproductive health care. But in the years since the president’s hand-picked Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, we’ve seen what it means when this freedom is taken away: Women bleeding out and even dying after being denied abortion care, teenage rape survivors crossing state lines to get an abortion, and American servicewomen stationed in states like Texas and Florida stripped of their reproductive rights. 

“Now, with full Republican control in Washington, we can’t risk anything in New Jersey. That’s why as governor, I’ll work to enshrine abortion rights into our state constitution and stockpile the abortion pill Mifepristone. 

“We know Republicans in this race will do the exact opposite — they’ve voted to defund Planned Parenthood and even support banning abortion across New Jersey. Let’s not forget, the last Republican governor of New Jersey defunded Planned Parenthood in every budget. 

“That’s why this race for governor is so important. We have an opportunity to chart a new path forward in 2025 and make sure New Jersey is a state that expands our rights and freedoms — not restricts them.” 

Since the fall of Roe v. Wade, Mikie has led the fight to protect women’s access to emergency abortion care, block efforts to ban medication abortion like mifepristone, and ensure military servicewomen have access to abortion and contraception, no matter where they are stationed. She also introduced legislation to stop the practice of “judge shopping” — a common tactic anti-abortion advocates use to hand-pick a court and outcome by filing lawsuits in single-judge divisions where they are all but assured to get a favorable outcome.

###

data.title: ICYMI: Mikie Sherrill Launches Gov Campaign With Support and Enthusiasm From Across NJ
data.description:
MONTCLAIR — This week, Mikie Sherrill launched her campaign for governor with a pledge to bring a different type of leadership and fresh perspective to Trenton. After her announcement — “Build Something” — Mikie hit the road to hear from New Jerseyans about the challenges they face, from housing to labor and health care costs, with stops in Paterson, New Brunswick, Red Bank, and Atlantic City.  

Mikie spoke with members of the community at Eva’s Village in PatersonMikie joined with members of NJFMBA in Atlantic City

Mikie has earned the support of a range of groups and individuals — before and after her launch — including organized labor, faith leaders, New Jersey’s grassroots organizers, and women: 

  • Laborers back Sherrill for Governor

  • New Jersey Firefighters Mutual Benevolent Association endorses Sherrill

  • EMILY's List endorses Rep. Mikie Sherrill in race for New Jersey governor

  • Dick Codey endorses Mikie Sherrill for governor

  • National, local women’s groups back Sherrill for governor

  • Newark clergy leader will back Sherrill for governor

  • Grassroots Morris groups want Sherrill for governor

  • McKeon endorses Sherrill for governor

Mikie heard from members of LiUNA working at the Rutgers Cancer Institute construction project in New Brunswick

You can see some of the highlights from the week below: 

NJ.com: Piloting NJ through the Trump era: Why Mikie Sherrill is running for governor

From leading a Navy helicopter squadron, to New Jersey in the Trump era, Rep. Mikie Sherrill says she’s ready for action: On Monday, she officially declared her candidacy for governor.

Sherrill, a former pilot and federal prosecutor, has served in the House since 2018, when she flipped a red district that hadn’t voted for a Democrat since 1982. Now, in a packed field for governor, she’s the only woman running. Hours after announcing, she spoke with the editorial board about this latest mission.

New Jersey Globe: Mikie Sherrill wants to be the transit, housing, and transparency-obsessed governor

Speaking with the New Jersey Globe this morning, Sherrill homed in on three issues that she plans on making her top priorities as governor: lowering housing costs, improving public transit, and increasing transparency in a state known for its shady politics. And she said that unlike other politicians [...] she’s committed to actually doing what needs to be done.

New Jersey Globe: Sherrill has mammoth $600k one-day fundraising haul

Rep. Mikie Sherill (D-Montclair) raised over $600,000 in her first 24 hours as an announced candidate for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, qualifying for matching funds under the state’s public financing program in just one day.

TapInto Paterson: Mikie Sherrill Kicks Off Gubernatorial Campaign at Eva’s Village, Tackling New Jersey’s Housing Crisis

Just one day after announcing her candidacy for governor, Congresswoman Mikie Sherrill (NJ-11) made her first campaign stop at Eva’s Village in Paterson, to address New Jersey’s housing crisis. Sherrill, a former U.S. Navy helicopter commander, federal prosecutor, and mother of four, emphasized the need for innovative solutions to ensure affordable housing is accessible to all residents.

Washington Post: Opinion | Can these Capitol Hill roommates lead Democrats out of the wilderness?

If the future of the Democratic Party hinges on its candidates connecting better with the pressures that average Americans are feeling, there might be no greater hope for the losing side at this moment than Abigail Spanberger of Virginia and Mikie Sherrill of New Jersey.

[...]

“Everyone here knows the opportunity that New Jersey affords, but nobody can afford New Jersey,” [Sherrill] told me. “Whether they’re making $50,000 year or $150,000 a year or more, it just feels like they’re not able to get ahead. They’re not able to get to stable ground. That’s why I’m running for governor, because I truly and deeply believe that well-run, efficient government can deliver for people.”

[...]

“I’d say that after serving in the military for years, especially at a time when women serving in the military was somewhat unusual and they were breaking through barriers — that kind of grit and determination, I think, has served me well as I’ve entered into the rough-and-tumble world of New Jersey politics,” Sherrill said.

Meidas Touch: Ben Interviews Rep. Mikie Sherrill As She Announces Run for NJ Governor

Turning to her gubernatorial run, Sherrill outlined a platform that combines defending democracy with tackling “kitchen table issues” like housing costs, childcare, and affordable healthcare. “It’s not enough to have a good defense. We need a strong offense to move forward,” she said, adding that Democratic governors are now the “main line of defense” against Trump’s overreach.

Fox5 New York: Mikie Sherrill enters New Jersey governor’s race

Q: You released a video today putting out your goals as governor – affordability, NJ TRANSIT, a lot of the issues we hear that have been proven incredibly difficult to fix for a number of governors of both parties. How would you break the logjam and get these fixed? 

Mikie: Well I think that’s exactly right. That’s why I’m running for governor — Trenton needs a new perspective and new leadership to take on the hard challenges, and that’s what I have a history of doing. I went to the Naval Academy and was in the Navy — and you know there you have to lead, follow, or get out of the way. 

“I think our Democratic governors are prepared to fight back, and that’s part of the reason I’m running. It’s not just that many of the things Trump is threatening to implement are against our ideals and values. It’s also an attack on the way our states run. As people remember, Trump was the architect of the State and Local Tax Deduction cap. He was the person who set up the Court that took down Roe. The president who refused [...] to fund the Gateway Tunnel. That’s why we need strong leadership, strong Democratic governors, to forge that path forward and continue to deliver for the American people.”
